But, in the event that extreme behaviour and vilification continues in the public domain, which this legislation is intended to redress, legislation of this kind, carefully drafted and reasonably applied, can play an important role as the final barrier to inflamed and ultimately dangerous vilification continuing unabated.

The fact is that religious tension activated the legislation: the legislation has not activated religious tension. Indeed, the problem has been with us for some timeâregrettably, perhaps more so, with the changed conditions following September 11. The act, rather than assuming a parity of culture and religion in the way the motion implies, merely addresses the certain effects actions would have if vilification of religion were to take place. Indeed, my own view is that religious and cultural identities intermingle. Freedom of religious belief and expression is a primary tenet of the democratic system, but such freedom does not forgive incitements and vilifications simply because someone is a Sikh, a Muslim or a Christian. This act makes that necessary balance law and, if prudently drafted, it will do the same in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: âDuring the debate on the motion, the member for Bruce indicated that he would approve my request to table a transcript of a speech given by Pastor Daniel Scot. I seek leave to table that document.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this House:

item.para: notes that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: since the abolition of the Commonwealth Dental Program waiting lists for dental services have increased by over 30 per cent;

item.label: (b)
item.para: an increasing number of Australians are unable to afford private dental treatment and are waiting up to 5 years for dental care;

item.label: (c)
item.para: older Australians, in particular, are at risk of poor health and a diminished quality of life as a result of long waiting lists and the lack of affordability of private dental services and private health insurance;

item.label: (d)
item.para: the working poor, ineligible for health care cards and unable to afford private health insurance, are either postponing essential dental care, or risking high interest health credit products to access essential dental care to avoid further work absence;

item.label: (e)
item.para: poor dental health can contribute to deterioration in overall health and can lead to premature admission to nursing homes or even death;

item.label: (f)
item.para: oral health issues are often divorced from mainstream health issues even though there is a strong link between poor dental health and health problems such as diabetes, stroke, heart disease, endocarditis, and nutritional deficiencies;

item.label: (g)
item.para: the postponement of dental treatment has led to an increase in the demand for emergency dental care, exacerbating ongoing preventative treatment which provides greatest long term benefits to both the community and the Commonwealth budget; and

item.label: (h)
item.para: early intervention is important for maintaining a healthy and quality lifestyle and reducing future burdens on the health system; and
calls on the Government to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: recognise Ben Chifleyâs vision when he amended the Constitution in 1946 to recognise dental treatment as a legitimate medical treatment;

item.label: (b)
item.para: acknowledge that existing policies, as highlighted by the House of Representatives Inquiry into Long Term Strategies for Ageing Over the Next 40 years, âfall short of providing access to preventative dental careâ;

item.label: (c)
item.para: reinstate a Commonwealth dental program, and adopt Laborâs Australian Dental Care plan; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: work cooperatively with the States and Territories to ensure that services are delivered to the most vulnerable in our community, including the elderly and the working poor.

speech.para: In South Australia the average waiting time for public dental health care reached 49 months in 2001. People were waiting more than four years on average to get their teeth fixed. That means that there were people who had been waiting even longer than that. That was the effect of the Commonwealth government pulling the plug on the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in 1996. It is almost 10 years since that cruel decision; ridiculously, South Australians are now celebrating a waiting list of just two years following the allocation of approximately $44 million by the state Labor government this year. What an absurd thing to be celebrating, yet in the three years since the Labor government was elected in South Australia waiting times have fallen by 45 per cent, or approximately 43,000 people.

It is an outrage that the Howard government cut the public dental program. I know of people in the electorate of Hindmarsh who died before they got to the top of the dental waiting list. Failing to fund dental health care seriously affects peopleâs quality of life. I cannot believe that in a country such as Australia pensioners are expected to find the funds to pay for private dental care. Maybe they can afford to do that in the suburbs of Bennelong or Wentworth, but I can guarantee that it is not so easy in the western suburbs of Adelaide, where I come from.

Poor oral health is linked to poor nutrition and a range of medical conditions, including diabetes, pneumonia and cardiovascular disease; yet somehow this government thinks it is okay for it to sit there with a $9 billion surplus and no funding for public dental health care. It is estimated that between 30 and 50 per cent of older people who enter hospital are undernourished. Poor dental care is a key reason for this and it is unacceptable for the Howard government and the members on the other side to ignore their responsibility. It is not just the elderly who are affected so badly by this. Childrenâs oral health has deteriorated since 1996. Labor remains committed to reintroducing a federal public dental care program, unlike members on the other side of the chamber.

It is deceitful to suggest that the states alone are responsible for dental services. The Constitution clearly gives the Commonwealth the responsibility. It was a priority for the federal Labor government, but it was one of the first casualties of the Howard government. When the Commonwealth Dental Health Program was scrapped there were 380,000 Australians waiting an average of six months for public dental services; by May 2000 that figure had skyrocketed to 500,000 people waiting between eight months and five years. What happens is that people on low incomes stop going to the dentist. They do not get check-ups, they put up with the pain and they struggle on. Many people will stop eating fresh fruit and vegetables because it hurts to chew. I am incredulous that any government could do this to people. These people are not asking for a handout; they are simply struggling to make ends meet.

Maybe people are going through a rough patch and cannot find work; maybe they work two low-paid jobs and still cannot scrape together the money to pay for their kids to go to the dentist; maybe they have worked and paid all of their lives and cannot afford to go to the dentist because the age pension just does not stretch far enough. Whatever the case, these are just regular Australians trying to live their lives the best way that they can. This government does not think it is up to them to fund a Commonwealth dental health program so that, regardless of your income, you can afford to go to the dentist.

talk.start.para: âWhat about the states?

âI know that the members opposite argue that this is a state issue or that in 1996 the Commonwealth scheme was only a temporary scheme, but the real issue here is that people who are suffering are not interested in the quarrelling that is taking place in here. They want their teeth fixed. The states have put in money. The real issue is that people who are suffering because of bad dental health care do not care: they are desperately in need of dental attention. The state Labor government in South Australia has put money into dental care and it is about time the Commonwealth did its part instead of just wiping its hands of any responsibility, as this government is currently doing.

speech.para: This is not a poor country. The Treasurer is not struggling to work out how he is going to pay for the thousands of new computers for government departments that will be bought this year or for the tax breaks he is giving to people earning over $100,000 a year, but he says a public dental health care program is not a priority. The priorities of the Howard government are wrong. I call upon this government to reinstate a Commonwealth dental program, to adopt Laborâs Australian dental care plan, and to work cooperatively with the states and territories to ensure that dental services are delivered to the most vulnerable in our community, including the elderly and the working poor.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI thank the member for Hindmarsh for bringing to the attention of the House the appalling state of this nationâs dental health system and for giving me the opportunity to speak on this issue. In 1993 the Commonwealth Labor government funded a four-year program to help the states to reduce their lengthy waiting list. This was a $245 million package deal over four years. The program was flawed from the beginning. There was a restricted range of services offered under the funding package. One was a low fee paid for referrals to private dentists, resulting in insufficient incentive for private practitioners to participate in the program; the program also excluded full and partial dentures as well as other services such as bridges, orthodontic work and crowns. The desired resultsâthe shortening of the statesâ waiting listsâdid not eventuate. We were led to believe that it did, but it did not.

speech.para: For example, in Queensland waiting lists were one month to 12 months at the beginning of 1993; now the waiting time is anything from one year to eight years. Why? Because the states, especially Queensland, saw the program as a cash cow. Their general practice dental careâwhat they were being funded for: tooth extractions and fillingsâtook priority, so any other work was delayed. Why? The states had to continue to fund other dental work, so they slowed the process. They thought that the Commonwealth would extend the funding if the waiting times did not decrease. The waiting time was extended for pensioners needing to have dentures fixed. Why? Because the Commonwealth Labor government excluded them from the service list.

The most vulnerable in our community, the age pensioners, are now suffering. Only recently a pensioner complained to me that so far he has had to wait five years for a set of denturesâand he still has not got his teethâand, naturally, he was concerned for his failing health because of his inability to chew proper food. The amazing thing is that, when he and many other aged constituents before him complained about the lack of dental services offered to them, they were told to go and see their federal member because the Howard government had cut dental funding.

As I said earlier, the 1993 Labor Commonwealth Dental Health Program was flawed because it never included funding for denture treatment. This is another example of the states shirking their responsibilities, blaming the Commonwealth and pushing those who require denture services further down the waiting list. To be forced to wait five years or more for a set of teeth is appalling. In Queensland alone there are 11,000 people on the waiting list for a set of denturesâmostly age pensioners. This is typical of the Beattie government in Queensland and the way they run our health system.

Another problem with Queensland Health is their record keeping. If you want a clear picture of their waiting list, it is not possible. Queensland Health do not have a system that collects data on average waiting times for routine check-ups. Queensland Health do not have a specific waiting list for routine dental check-ups, so how is it possible for Beattie to know or provide figures on the number of people on waiting lists through Queenslandâs oral health program? However, one wonders if these waiting lists are as bad as they are made out, because I notice that the most recent figures released by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare showed that the stateâs funding for dental care was $374 million in the year 2000 but that in the last financial year all the state spent was $342 million, a reduction in funding. You would have to question why the states would cut their funding while waiting lists grew. Surely they would not allow the most vulnerable in our society to suffer just to milk the Commonwealth of more funds to service a health system that they are clearly responsible for.

It is about time the states stopped playing games, started showing some responsibility and spent the extra funds they receive under the Commonwealth health agreement, the GST windfall, on dental health care. The Howard government have accepted their role of responsibility by providing approximately $350 million annually under the private health insurance rebate of 30 per cent for ancillary dental services and $75 million on dental health services for our war veterans and providing dental services to members of the armed forces and the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. The Commonwealth funds university training for dentists and other dental service providers and also subsidises drugs that may be prescribed for oral health under the PBS.

As I have said in this House before, I do not believe that a huge amount of money needs to be thrown into the public dental health system, but rather it needs opening up to a bit of competition. I would suggest that the government introduces a system of vouchers that may be redeemed in either the public clinics or private hospitals. I am also not sure that public clinics should be located in our hospital systems, taking up valuable space. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise in support of this motion on dental care. I commend the member for Hindmarsh, Mr Georganas, for moving it because dental care is a major health issue in Australia today. In my electorate of Richmond, where we have many elderly people and many people on low incomes, dental health is an issue that people raise with me on a daily basis. It is disappointing that this government does not take seriously its responsibility for the dental health of its citizens. As I said, every day I hear stories of local people who have been waiting for years often just to have basic dental work done.

speech.para: When the Leader of the Opposition was in my electorate recently, I took the opportunity to introduce him to three local people: Norm Masters, Jill Wainwright and Allan Green. Norm Masters has been waiting for around a year to get his dentures refitted. At the moment he is barely able to eat or speak because his dentures simply fall out of his mouth. On the many occasions I have met with him, his dentures have completely fallen out of his mouth. It is an outrageous situation. Jill Wainwright has broken a tooth and has given up on public dental after two years on the waiting list. It will cost her $800 to get her tooth fixed. Allan has spent about $6,000 in dental care costs because he, too, has given up after waiting for two years. These are people who have been forced to pay for dental care, but thousands of others cannot afford to pay for it and are just waiting in pain.

Also, recently in Ballina, which is in the adjoining electorate of Page, a local elderly woman had to wait five years to get her teeth fixed. It is unfortunate that the member for Page does not stand up for her and speak, as I am doing today, about reinstating the federal funding for dental care. Instead, he chose to say in the local newspaper, âOh, it is an issue for the states.â I have news for the member for Page. It is not. It is a federal government responsibility. He should be in here standing up for this woman in Ballina who has been waiting five years. It is an outrageous situation.

This situation of people having to wait for years to get their teeth fixed is clearly unacceptable, and it is impossible for the federal government to justify. I have heard hundreds of these stories. Elderly people and young families who cannot afford to see a private dentist have simply been abandoned by this government. Members of parliament on the other side of the House refuse to take up the fight for their constituents. It seems they are happy for people in their electorates to wait years to get their teeth fixed. It seems they are happy for people in their electorates to be living in pain. Instead of telling the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing that they need to invest in dental care, they spend their time buck passing and carping on about the states. It is just not good enough. Just to enlighten coalition members, I draw their attention to section 51 of the Australian Constitution, which gives the federal government responsibility for dental health. I was very disappointed in the recent budget that there was no provision for dental health. Instead of taking this constitutional responsibility seriously, the government scrapped the $100 million a year Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme in 1997. This was despite the Minister for HealthÂ and Ageing himself saying:

quote.para: The Keating governmentâs program did reduce waiting times. No doubt about that.

speech.para: Perhaps he can explain to the 4,000 people in Richmond who have signed a petition calling for the funding to be restored just why he refuses to take responsibility for their dental health. Unfortunately, it is not just the dental health of local people that the health minister is putting at risk. Recent studies have shown that poor dental health can lead to a range of general health problems. Poor dental health can contribute to strokes, heart disease and chronic infections and it can also make diabetes difficult to manage. By not providing adequate public dental heath care, the federal government is putting the health of local seniors and families at risk. I just will not stand for it, particularly in my electorate, where 20 per cent of people are aged over 65. That is why dental health is such a major issue.

The government is simply not providing enough public dentists to cater for the demand. There are only about 240 public dentists to cater for more than 2.5 million health care card holders, children and the elderly. The government needs to train more dentists and to provide them with more incentive to treat public patients. It is time to stop the buck passing. I am happy to work with anyone, including members opposite, to make sure that public dental funding is restored by the federal government. I call on coalition members of parliament to support this motion and stop blaming everybody else but their own government for this problem. Make no mistake: it is the federal government that is obligated to provide dental health care and this government is not meeting its constitutional obligation.

talk.start.para: âHonourable members opposite have made a compelling case for more spending to improve dental health care in Australia. They have outlined some situations of people who clearly need additional funding and clearly need access to dental health services. Nobody denies the sincerity of those honourable members opposite who have supported the motion currently before the chamber. However, while they have outlined the need for improved dental health, they have not explained to us why the state and territory governments of Australia refuse to carry out their responsibility to provide dental health care services of an adequate level. Every last cent of the GST money goes to the states and territories of Australia. One of the reasons that all of the GST funds are paid in this way is so that the states and territories would then be able to fund their constitutional responsibilities.

speech.para: One of the difficulties we have had in Australia since the Second World War, when most of the taxing powers moved to the Commonwealth, was that the states had a range of constitutional responsibilities but not the financial wherewithal to meet them. The introduction of the new tax system and the GST has meant that unprecedented amounts of money are flowing into the state and territory treasuries. I understand that the windfall to the Queensland state Labor government alone is over half a billion dollars. This has given Mr Bracks, Mr Beattie, Mr Carr and all of the other premiers and chief ministers the ability to fund dental health care services.

Governments have a different and complementary role in assisting Australians with their dental health. Both the Australian government and the state and territory governments must do their fair share for the system to work properly. Everyone knows that the states and territories are responsible for public dental services. As part of the Australian health care agreements, states and territories are required to report on the number of dental services provided. All states and territories have programs of universally available, free or reduced cost school based dental care. They are also allowed to levy a patient charge for dental services.

Nobody denies that there are lengthy waiting lists for some public dental programs. However, this situation could be radically improved if the states and territories used the money that flows to them from the GST to adequately fund these services. So we find these tear-jerking stories introduced to the House by the member for Hindmarsh and others. These stories could easily be fixed. These tragic situations could be dramatically improved if the states and territories of Australia used the GST money they receive to improve funding of health services in the dental area.

Let us look at what the Australian government has been spending during 2004-05 for dental services. This funding consists of money from the private health insurance 30 per cent rebate for ancillary services. The dollar value attributable to dental services in the 12 months to March 2005 was $359 million. The Department of Veteransâ Affairs estimates expenditure on dental care as $75 million per annum. The Department of Defence also provides dental services to members of the armed forces, and these costs are included in the health component of their budgets. There is also the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health.

Much has been made by the member for Hindmarsh and the member for Richmond of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program. Let us look at this program. From 1994 until 1996, the Commonwealth Dental Health Program provided limited funding of $278 million over four years to the states and territories to reduce excessive waiting times and improve access to public services. This meant that the Commonwealth government of the day was assisting the states who were not carrying out their constitutional responsibilities to provide adequate funding for public dental health services. While the program was part of the election campaign of the Australian Labor Party in 1993, it is very important to recognise that the ALP made absolutely no commitment to keeping the program beyond 1996.

With evidence of substantial reductions in waiting times around the country, the Australian government took the decision to abolish the dental program in the 1996-97 budget and funding ceased on 1 January 1997. It was by nature a one-off program. There were problems with it and the states, now that the GST is flowing through to their coffers, do have the financial ability to properly fund public health services in the dental area. The question that honourable members ought to be asking is: why are the Labor governments in the states and territories failing Australians? Why are the state and territory governments preventing adequate public dental health funding? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to support this excellent motion on dental care. In reflecting on this motion, I went to an appropriation bill contribution by my predecessor, Gareth Evans. This was the appropriation bill in 1996-97, and Mr Evans, the former member for Holt, was talking about the abolition of the Commonwealth dental scheme. He said this, rather presciently:

quote.para: There is the abolition of the Commonwealth dental scheme, with stunningly widespread implications for elderly Australians and indeed many other categories of the four million Australians presently in receipt of health care cards and eligible for that assistance. Something over 500,000 Australians accessed that scheme last year. I know, from moving around the country and looking at my own electorate, what the implications of that are. In Tasmania alone, I think 14,000 people are on the waiting list at the moment. All of these people will go back to the bad old days of feeling pain, distress, discomfort, social liability and job liabilityâeventually having their teeth fall out or being extracted as a last resort ...

speech.para: In speaking to that appropriation bill, Gareth Evans made the following second reading amendment:

quote.para: â¦ the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Programme will cause serious problems for the less well off â¦

speech.para: How prescient that is. At the time of that particular speech, we had a waiting list of 380,000 Australians, I think it was, who were waiting on average about six months. At present, we have some 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years.

It is interesting that there is a dichotomy between state and federal governments and who takes responsibility for this. I have a couple of points. A number of speakers on the other side have already mentioned the fact that the Commonwealth government already funds dental health programs, so it has already put its foot into the water, so to speak. It abolished the Dental Health Program in 1996. However, it continues to play a direct role in the provision of dental care services for veterans, Indigenous persons and the armed services and some in-patient services under Medicare and dental care related to the cleft lip and cleft palate scheme, which is about three per cent of the public dental health budget. So the fact is that the Commonwealth does make a welcome contribution in that area.

These debates are interesting. We have had debates about water in the states and the gun buyback after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre. We talk about the division between the states and the federal government. When the issue is large enough, like water for example, there is a thing called the Council of Australian Governments which, when problems are identified, comes together for a common resolution. If we have something like 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years for dental health services, I think that is a national crisisâcorrect me if I am wrongâparticularly given the health defects that causes. It is incumbent upon the government to provide further funding and have a COAG meeting. As I said, they can fund water incentive programs et cetera.

We cannot continue to tolerate this situation. In my electorate, the three services that actually provide dental health programs are the Casey Community Health Service at its Berwick site, the Casey Community Health Service at its Cranbourne site and the City of Greater Dandenong Community Health Service. It takes 2Â½ years to get an examination, 2Â½ to get an X-ray, 2Â½ years to get a filling, 2Â½ years to get an extraction and up to five years to get dentures repaired. It is incumbent upon a government that spent $66 billion in its election budget and $21 billion in tax cuts to realise that it is not going to take much more money to fix this problem.

An evaluation of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program was conducted by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare in 1996. It found that in the 24 months following the introduction of the CDHP, 200,000 additional persons received publicly funded dental care in one year, there was a greater frequency of visits and waiting times were reducedâthose waiting for less than one month increased from 47.5 per cent to 61.5 per cent. If we have a common commitment rather than blaming the states for not fixing this dental health problemâand I am sure we will hear some point scoring soonâwe can fix this problem. I call upon the government to take this issue seriously. Spend some of the $87 billion on fixing a national crisis in the health of our Australian community.

talk.start.para: âIt is a great pleasure to debate in the House this motion, under private membersâ business, on dental health. I see hypocrisy in some of the speakers on the other side of the chamber feigning that the only people interested in their constituentsâ health, including their dental health, are from the opposition side. I ask members like the member for Richmond just exactly how many approaches she has made to the state Labor government about the failing dental system. I ask what the member is doing to ensure that her state Labor government is meeting its obligation rather than reducing its budget on dental health.

speech.para: It is very obvious to me that in every state there is a political tactic being played here. This political tactic is being played with the lives of Australians. What is taking place now is that the states have got togetherâremember, all the states and territories are Laborâand they are saying, âWe will reduce funding, the system will collapse and then we can blame the Commonwealth.â Do you know what I think? I think the federal opposition is aiding and abetting this position and is actually aware of the appalling action being taken by the states.

I say this because, from the information I have, in 2002-03 the total amount of all state funding combined was $342 million. That was down from $374 million in 1999-2000. That is, the combined funding of every state and territory for dental works has fallen. What the member for Forde would have indicated had she been able to finish her speech in the House is exactly right: she believes that a voucher system has merit, that private dental practitioners would be a valuable resource in helping the public system to cope with the apparent overload and that a change in the public system to bring about efficiency should be that dentists working in public practices be paid per service and not salaried. This would make them more accountable and the go-slow process for more funding would not be considered.

The member for Forde has quite rightly validated my point in this debate by saying that in 1994 to 1996, when the Commonwealth Labor government put in place an interim dental health program with a definite sunset for 1996âno funding beyond 1996âthere was a go-slow to ensure that the Commonwealth funding was continued. Waiting lists in many of those areas actually increased rather than decreased. Instead of something taking place and something being done for the people of Australia, there was an organised go-slow in order to retain and continue that Commonwealth funding. What a shame.

I look at this situation and I believe every speaker wants something done about the dental services and about many services across Australia. But the responsibility must lie with the state governments, particularly in this area. Do you pay your neighbourâs mortgage simply because the neighbour is in arrears? It is their responsibility; it is not your responsibility. I am constantly bombarded with calls. It does not matter whether it is a new police stationââThe Commonwealth has a surplus; the states are in deficit so the Commonwealth should pay.â It does not matter whether it is a new hospitalââThe Commonwealth has a surplus, let the Commonwealth build a new hospital because the states are in deficit, so the Commonwealth must pay.â How long do we reward the state Labor governments for mismanagement? How long do we reward them for failure in governance and financial accountability? We cannot continue to carry the can for the state governments. It is probably time and there is opportunity for states to be removed from the equation. Perhaps the Minister for Health and Ageing could withhold funding from the states. The previous speaker, the member for Holt, spoke about COAGâ

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âI have been watching the current debate about a debate regarding nuclear power with some interest. For reasons that are unknown, sections of the Australian media, particularly the newspaper the Australian, have been asking anybody with vague relevance to comment on whether or not we should have a debate. Predictably, nobody is opposed to having a debate, and so even opponents of nuclear power are then able to be portrayed as calling for nuclear power to be re-examined or reconsidered. In fact we have had debate on this issue interminably. Debate has never stopped about nuclear power. What does wax and wane of course is media interest. Now we have a particular media outlet promoting the nuclear cause hard there is inevitably more public focus, but the debate remains essentially the same as it always has.

speech.para: The crucial point is that the onus is on those who are advocating change to demonstrate why that change should occur. As a member of the Labor Party I know only too well that that onus rests on all of us who advocate change. Advocates of nuclear power have an onus to demonstrate a genuinely commercial market for energy without the huge subsidies that have characterised nuclear power in other markets particularly in Europe and with genuinely accounted for external costs, such as the additional cost required to protect installations from terrorist threats, the cost of waste disposal, decommissioning and other issues, properly factored into the equation. In other words, the proponents of nuclear power have an onus to demonstrate how Australia would benefit economically as a result of a move to nuclear power, taking into account the primary rationale which is currently advanced, which is of course to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. They also have to explain how they would deal with issues such as the location of nuclear power installations in Australia and how waste disposal would be dealt with. And, most importantly of all, they would need to explain how we would continue to export vast amounts of coal at the same time as seeking to reduce Australiaâs own coal consumption. Surely that would be rather hypocritical.

These associated issues are central to the question of nuclear power and whether or not we are to take the question of externalities into account in the equation that governs what energy we use and what we pay for it. We also have to take into account the externalities of other forms of power if we are to properly consider the questions of greenhouse gases and the impact that coal- and gas-fired power has on our greenhouse gas emissions. So clearly, in any examination of nuclear power as an alternative, we need to look at the external implications such as waste disposal, decommissioning costs, security costs and the like as well as the raw economic cost in the same way that we are looking at the external impact of coal and gas producing greenhouse gas emissions in that equation. Similarly, we also need to take into account external factors relating to other forms of power such as wind power and the impact on rural landscapes.

Unfortunately, we do not always get consistency in these debates. New South Wales Premier Bob Carr has recently called for a rethink about nuclear power. But on 7 June he said that he refused to have any nuclear waste dump established in New South Wales. This to me is an amazingly contradictory and confused position. If nuclear waste is so bad that we cannot even contemplate having it stored in our state, how can we advocate introducing the process that creates it? Clearly, this is a perfect illustration of one of the key issues with nuclear power: in order to advocate it you have got to include all of the aspects of the issue within your proposition. You cannot pretend that issues like nuclear waste are going to be somebody elseâs problem.

It is worth scrutinising the broader position of some of those who have been advocating nuclear power, as an inevitable major public relations campaign winds up, and see what their track record is on other issues. Bob Carr certainly does not fit into this category but I have no doubt that others advocating nuclear power have probably also got a bit of a track record at being greenhouse sceptics. I would be interested to see what their view is on the issue of nuclear proliferation and whether or not Iran should be enabled to develop civilian nuclear capability, which of course many feel is linked to a desire to develop nuclear weapons. Advocates of nuclear power have a responsibility to address all of these issues, including the nuclear weapons proliferation issue, which is, I believe, the biggest single security threat to our world.

The fallacy that always permeates these debates is the failure of those involved in them to deal with the consumption question. For years Australians have debated issues like new power stations and alternative energy sourcesâbe it wind or nuclear powerâbut have often overlooked the fundamental question of how we reduce our consumption of energy and how we make our existing consumption more efficient by using new technology. At one level this is understandable, because the simplest way to reduce consumption, of course, is to increase price. It is very clear that substantial increases in price for energy would have an enormously retrograde effect on lower income people. There would be a devastating social impact. That is one of the key issues that the advocates of nuclear power have to deal with because, almost by definition, unless the price of coal- and gas-fired power in Australia is substantially raised to take into account greenhouse, for example, then nuclear could not be competitive. It is almost automatic that anybody advocating nuclear power as a viable power source for Australia is by definition, if they are going to have any kind of working energy market, advocating very substantial increases in the price of electricity for ordinary Australians.

There are other options, though, and I want to raise one of them today. This one is currently being promoted to state governments like New South Wales, and it is designed to eliminate or reduce the need for new power stations through using smart metering based on digital metering technology and modern telecommunications technology, enabling consumers to manage their own use and to choose when they use particular appliances and ensuring that they can manage the costs of their own electricity consumption. California is introducing this system after trials showed drops of between 12 and 35 per cent in peak period consumption of electricity. Bayard Capital and Country Energy are trialling this in 200 households in New South Wales where consumers have variable prices for electricity depending on the time of day and they have the technology to enable them to choose when they should use particular appliances. At a cost of about $4 to $5 per month for the metering technology, consumers are able to substantially diminish their electricity bills.

This presents a potential to reduce the effective gap between base load and peak load power demand. That gap is ultimately a measure of our efficiency in delivering and using electricity, because the bigger that gap the more inefficiently we are investing. We are building power stations that are ultimately there to ensure that we have enough electricity on the half-dozen days of the year when everybody has got their airconditioners on. By making sure that that gap is minimised, we reduce the extent to which we have to invest capital in enormous power stations that are incredibly capital intensive and therefore we reduce costs to consumers by ensuring that the differences, the ebbs and flows of consumption, are smoothed out. By giving consumers the choice through smart metering technology that enables them to do that, we will reduce that gap.

Bayard is proposing something that I describe as a reverse user-pays model where customers will voluntarily agree not to use certain appliances like airconditioners at particular times of the day or on specified days and, as a result, they will get a standard rate reduction in their electricity rate. The same principle applies to congestion charging on roads. These issues matter. New South Wales is currently contemplating investing in a new coal-fired power station, partly the cause of their interest in the nuclear debate, at a cost conservatively estimated at a billion dollars. This is primarily in order to deal with this problem of the gap between base load and peak load power. Smart meters could obviate the need for a new power station and would have a variety of other benefits including information about consumer use, fault detection benefits, automated meter reading and other things.

I do not have airconditioning in my home but, in the current system, if a new power station is to be built in order to ensure that there is enough power when there is a peak use of airconditioning in Melbourne then I will be paying for the power station even though I do not have airconditioning. So this smarter approach that is being put forward by Bayard Capital and being developed in California has got a lot to recommend it. It is important to emphasise that there is no magic bullet, be it nuclear power or smart metering. But it is illustrative of how we can address greenhouse problems by getting a lot smarter about how we do things and using new technology to massively improve our performance of energy use and reduce our consumption by moving forward, rather than by blindly reverting to old solutions that may help solve the greenhouse problem but that bring a lot of other problems with them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to deal with another resource issue and that is water. The capital cities of Australia are facing high and dry times. It seems to me that it does not matter whether it is Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide or Perth, the average water supply available to those cities is at 40 per cent of capacity. Some are below that level; some are slightly above itâon average, they have 40 per cent of their water supply left. The city of Sydney, I understand, has roughly, at current usage rates, two years water supply left. There have been numerous inquiries into the water needs of Sydney and Australia. There was The value of water: inquiry into Australiaâs urban water management report from the Senate inquiry in 2002, the Wentworth Group in 2004 and Pratt Water in 2005, just to name three really significant in-depth studies of water needs and pricing structures for water.

speech.para: Desalination appears to be the answer for New South Wales, according to the Premier as well as the water KGB. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I know you have not seen them in Melbourneâthey drive yellow vehicles and they lurk round the suburbs hoping to catch an unsuspecting suburbanite spraying their lawns at the wrong time or washing their car at an hour of the day or in a manner not approved by the Carr government. Those are the two policies. I know the Premier has dismissed the generation of electricity by wind in order to drive a desalination plant because it is a kookaburra-killing exercise. I did not realise, until he made this enlightened statement, that wind power kills kookaburras. Therefore, it is off the agenda for the state of New South Wales and we will be depending on nuclear power linked with a desalination plant. It is just a small budgetary item of $2 billion or $3 billion. That is $2 billion or $3 billion to solve the water problems of Sydney. There will probably be a six- or 10-year delay before we actually get it, but Sydney has water sufficient for two years. I am concerned that the water KGB and the desalination plant are not really going to solve some of the problems for Sydney or for some of the other capital cities around Australia.

Dams have never been lower than they are at the moment and we have, just up the road from Canberra, the tragic circumstances of the city of Goulburn facing the prospect of drinking water only and one shower a week. That is the rationing Goulburn is currently facing. A Sydney Morning Herald article said:

quote.para: Scientist Tim Flannery predicts that one morning in the not-too-distant future in one of the major cities, taps will be turned on, and instead of water, there will be just a whistling sound coming down the pipes.

speech.para: That would be something too terrible to contemplate. The article goes on to say:

quote.para: ... Charles Essery says that such a scenario is unlikely but not impossible.

speech.para: Charles Essery, a former executive of Sydney Water, said that there is no real plan to solve these problems in any of the cities of Australia.

quote.para: âWe are just two years away from a real emergency in Sydney, where water would only be available for drinking,â he said.

speech.para: Only three years ago, Warragamba Dam, Sydneyâs major supply, was 86 per cent full. The article went on:

quote.para: A recent report by Auditor-General Bob Sendtâ

speech.para: in New South Walesâ

quote.para: found a small increase in population growth could âturn Sydneyâs water surplus into a deficitâ.

speech.para: That is exactly what is happening now. It appears to be a policy in New South Wales, a whole-of-government approach that seems to be: âFingers crossed, letâs hope it rains.â The people of Goulburn do not think that is good policy, I do not think it is a good policy and people in the burgeoning, expanding suburbs of Sydney do not think it is a good policy either.

If we look at the budget and the way in which water resources have been looked at in the Sydney region we will see that in 1960 Warragamba Dam was completed for a population of one million people. In 1998, seven years ago, the dam was at capacity. Now the population is five million people and the storage is 37 per cent full. The major Sydney supply was full six or seven years ago and it is now serving a population of five million people instead of one million people. The state government in 2005-06 is spending $406 million on state-wide water infrastructure. This includes $86 million to access deep water stores in Warragamba, Nepean and Avon dams and the introduction of a fund of $30 million to encourage water saving projects by business.

By the way, you would be shocked to know that the Country Towns Water Supply and Sewerage Program of $85 million, which was promised this year, has a budget allocation of only $32 million. So the budget for country town water supplies has been cut by two-thirds. That alone is a cause of great concern, I would imagine, for my country colleagues. There has been no modelling or preparation. Nothing has been done.

What do the experts say should be done to resolve this issue? There are a number of principles or philosophies that could easily be applied to maximise the existing investment by making sure that the reticulation systems are properly used and properly maintained. There is a redundancy in the current system that can be easily taken up. There must be management of demandâand the state government has done that, but not sufficiently wellâby educating consumers and landowners about how they can make better use of valuable water.

A charging regime should also be used. I noticed today that there has been talk by Frank Sartor, the New South Wales minister, that he is going to have a dual pricing system: one for residents of homes and another one for industry. The people in homes have copped it so far. They have had to put up with the rationing program, and it seems to me they are going to cop another price rise and a regime for industry that will just be a flat rate. There are no programs by which industries can improve their efficiency.

The diversity of supply needs to be looked at. I believe we have to look at how we can recycle all the stormwater that is running out to sea. It is much cheaper to recycle stormwater than to build a desalination plant. A desalination plant has to turn salt water into fresh water whereas stormwater is only slightly polluted and can easily be upgraded for use in gardens, toilets and other uses around the suburbs.

The maximum use of local water harvesting schemes is something that the Commonwealth is going to encourage through its program under the National Water Commission, recently established by the Deputy Prime Minister. There needs to be maximisation of rainwater harvestingâthat is, collecting local rainfall by making sure that there is compulsory collection onsite by tanks and detaining basins or investment in retention, whether it be in the form of underground tanks or larger dam-like structures. And there must be truly cost-effective pricing.

Those are some of the principles. I know that Dr Charles Essery has made presentations here in Parliament House and I have been delighted to see that there is some imagination. Unfortunately he has left the water board. I know that within CSIRO and the Water Commission there are solutions, but there are no solutions in the New South Wales government, apparently. The New South Wales government seems incapable of facing these issues. My colleague Pat Farmer, the member for Macarthur, finds that he is going to have another 100,000 homes built in his area. In the electorate of Mitchell there will be another 60,000 homes.

There have been no plans for water supply, no vision, and no dedication of any type to the way in which those water needs are going to be met. And yet we have experts, up hill and down dale, saying that Sydney is facing a water crisis which needs to be dealt with. Frank Sartor, in his reign, has been a disaster and Bob Carr, in posing around the country side claiming to have solutions, is applying just a piecemeal approach to a sustainable water cycle for Sydney. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI grieve about the culture of favours for mates and special deals which infest the National Party in northern New South Wales. A significant wake-up call has come in the shape of the public inquiry into the Tweed Shire Council, whose first reportlast month led to the dismissal of the Tweed Shire Council. That inquiry outed a massive developer funded campaign to elect sympathetic candidates to the Tweed Shire Councilâcandidates with National Party links who would make decisions on council in the interests of these developers.

speech.para: The developersâ campaign, called Tweed Directions, raised over $340,000 from donors. It gave $163,000 to nine separate groups of candidates and dummy candidates which it ran during the campaign. It therefore had a further $177,000 available to spend on its own separate campaign in support of these candidates and to denigrate rival candidates. But Tweed Directions has declared that its electoral expenditure, aside from gifts, was $342,000. To the inquiry it changed this amount to $307,000âbut whichever amount is correct, it leaves an amount of between $143,000 and $165,000 unaccounted for. I urge the New South Wales Election Funding Authority to pursue this matter and to ascertain the source of this massive disclosure irregularity. I think the size of this campaign and its potential to buy councillors and improperly influence decisions about planning applications is cause for grave concern.

Not only did the inquiry unmask the developer campaign; it also unearthed decisions made by councillors who were beneficiaries of this campaign which inappropriately benefited these same developers. For example, in June 2003 councillors Warren Polglase, Don Beck, Gavin Lawrie, Wendy Marshall and Phil Youngblutt consented to an application by Resort Corporation, a company headed by the son and son-in-law of one of their colleagues, Councillor Brinsmead, for a large development at Kingscliff. They ignored the council officersâ recommendations on the height of the building. They approved the building in such a way as to save the developers over $33,000 in section 64 and section 94 contributions. Later on, they reduced the contributions payable by even more, approved illegal works and allowed the developer to reduce the width of the driveway from six metres to four metres. Resort Corporation was a major contributor to the campaigns of these councillors.

Then there was Chiltern Hunt, who put forward a 56-lot rural/residential subdivision at Terranora Road, Terranora. Councillors rejected their officersâ recommendation that they express a preference for a revised proposal with two fewer residential lots and more open space. Instead, council approved the development and, for good measure, threw in an additional residential lot, a reduction in pavement widths, removal of the requirement to construct kerbing and guttering along the full frontage of the site and a reduction in the length of the footway/cycleway. These concessions, which came without explanation, gave the developer a windfall in saved costs estimated at a cool $582,000. Little wonder that Chiltern Hunt subsequently donated $10,000 to these councillors through Tweed Directions.

These councillors who were so disgracefully in the developersâ pockets had deep National Party links. Councillor Lynne Beck was the wife of long-time National Party state MP Don Beck. Councillor Warren Polglase was a campaign director for Don Beck and Larry Anthony. Councillors Gavin Lawrie, Phil Youngblutt and Wendy Marshall joined the National Party after they became councillors. These National Party councillors are unfit to be councillors. They have no understanding of the importanceâor, indeed, the meaningâof conflict of interest. National Party Mayor Warren Polglase was asked by the Tweed inquiry:

quote.para: Having obtained funding from Tweed Directions, knowing that the underlying funding has come from a number of developers, if such an application by one of the people funding Tweed Directions comes before council, does that give rise to a conflict of interest on your part?

speech.para: Mr Polglase answered:

quote.para: I believe not.

speech.para: This complete failure to understand his responsibilities not only renders Mr Polglase unfit to be a councillor but also renders him unfit to be a member of the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee. The members of the area consultative committees are the responsibility of the Deputy Prime Minister. I know it may hurt the Deputy Prime Minister to ditch a National Party mate, but it has to be done. Area consultative committees are involved in the allocation of hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayersâ funds via Regional Partnerships and other government programs. They are subject to conflict of interest provisionsâand they need to be, because the risk of insider trading and grants going to the ACCsâ friends and member organisations is all too real.

Someone who does not understand conflict of interest when it is staring him in the faceâsuch as Warren Polglaseâshould not be a member of an area consultative committee. His understanding of conflict of interest reminds me of the late Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and the separation of powers. And it is not merely the conflict of interest issue and his conduct as a Tweed Councillor that are of concern. In April 2001 Warren Polglase was appointed to the position of Dairy Regional Assistance Program project officer by the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee. Just why Mr Polglase was superior to other applicants for the position is unclear. But he certainly had one thing going for him: he had been a member of the area consultative committee and, therefore, had been involved with the appointment of the very people who in turn chose him as project officer.

As Dairy RAP project officer, Warren Polglase got the area consultative committee and Minister Andersonâs department to approve a $273,000 grant to Seawind. In answer to a question from me, the Deputy Prime Minister claimed that this grant was approved following âa rigorous assessment processâ and âexternal financial checksâ. Seawindâs manager, Bob Hinchcliffe, was happy to line up his workers for a government media stunt involving former member Larry Anthony and his campaign director Warren Polglase. But after just 17 months the company shut down, making a laughing stock of the Deputy Prime Ministerâs ârigorous assessment processâ. On the basis of Mr Polglaseâs recommendation, $164,000 of taxpayersâ money has been wasted.

Mr Polglase also recommended an allocation of $88,000 under the Dairy Regional Assistance Program to create farm-stay accommodation on the Forest Glen Organic Farmâwhich is now on the market, for saleâwithout that farm-stay accommodation ever having been established or provided.

And it gets worse. Former councillor and Liberal Party member Bronwynne Luff has stated that, in 1992, Councillor Warren Polglase and other councillors whom she describes as âthe Midas majorityâ voted to rezone riverfront land near Boydâs Bay Bridge from âspecial business waterfrontâ to âurban expansionâ, allowing a development of 10 storeys rather than three. Bronwynne Luff says that, after the then state National Party minister allowed five storeys on the site, Warren Polglase said to her, âHow would you feel about the land becoming a public park?ââsuggesting that the state government would buy it from the owner. She was scandalised and said, âYou mean that, after increasing the value on paper, you would see the public purse buy it back for more than itâs worth?â

It appears that a similar trick was pulled more recently, in 2001, with $268,000 of federal taxpayersâ money, with land known as the Bilambil sports grounds. The land had been bought by Mr Peter Hutton, who told Tweed Council he wanted to sell it to them for $1 million. Councillor Luff supported the council officersâ view that council should pay no more than $900,000 for it. The land in question adjoins Bilambil Creek. It is flood prone and constrained, by zonings, to limited land use such as sports fields, but Councillor Polglase pressed for council to pay the full price asked by Mr Hutton. National Party sympathisers organised local demonstrations in support of the purchase. Then, mysteriously and miraculously, Minister Andersonâs department provided $268,000 under the Regional Solutions Program to assist with the purchase. The council paid $1.1 million for the land. Mr Peter Hutton, a very satisfied customer, then held a fundraising party at his home at The Anchorage at Tweed Heads for the benefit of the former National Party MP for Richmond, Larry Anthony. The circle is complete. Mr Anthony uses taxpayersâ funds to benefit Mr Hutton, who repays the favour with fundraising help. Taxpayersâ dollars are laundered into Larry Anthonyâs campaign funds, with Warren Polglase acting as the middleman.

These practices are not fit for a modern society which seeks to avoid corruption. The National Partyâs use of land rezoning and dodgy planning decisions for its political and financial benefit in the Northern Rivers of New South Wales is deplorable. The Deputy Prime Minister must clean up his party in New South Wales. He should start by removing Mr Polglase from the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee. The Deputy Prime Ministerâs statement to me in question time today that he was not aware of Mr Polglaseâs evidence to the Tweed inquiry is not good enough. He ought to be aware of such a serious matter, he ought to be reading that committee of inquiryâs report and he ought to be acting to ensure that members of his area consultative committees understand the concept of conflict of interest.

talk.start.para: âThere never was a war on poverty; maybe there was a skirmish on poverty. In the last five years there has been a chance to return to that war, and it is to that grievance that I speak today. The Millennium Summit in September 2000 was followed by the Monterey International Conference on Financing for Development in 2002 and, in that same year, the World Summit on Sustainable Development. Those three key meetings have laid the platform for United Nations member nations, including Australia, to find the resources required to meet the Millennium Development Goals. I am encouraged that will occur not only with the wealthy countries but also the middle-earning countries of the world and that there will be a mobilising of the domestic resources within the poorest countries as well.

speech.para: The eight goals and their underlying 18 targets bear repeating today. They are: halving hunger by the year 2015; halving extreme poverty by the year 2015; halting and beginning to turn around the scourge of HIV-AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis; dropping by three-quarters maternal mortality; reducing by two-thirds paediatric mortality; bringing at least to 50 per cent of current levels those who do not have access to safe drinking water; ensuring that the principles of sustainable development are enshrined in these goals; achieving significant improvements for 100 million slum dwellers worldwide; making available primary education worldwide by 2015 and removing the disparity of gender biases in primary and secondary education right now and then having them removed from education completely by 2015; and, finally, achieving a global partnership for development. That means fair trade and finance, debt reliefâand we had the welcome news two weeks ago of cancellation of debtâspecial programs for island and land-locked economies, productive work programs for youth, preventative medicines through collaboration with pharmaceutical companies and new technologies being available to the worldâs poor, particularly in communications and IT, which provide struggling economies with a leap-frogging ability.

Australiaâs contribution to the growth and stability of our region is significant. Australiaâs aid program focuses on strengthening governance, maximising the benefits of globalisation to allow investment liberalisation, regional securityâbecause without that the very hard won gains can be lostâand basic health and education. It also focuses onâmost important of allâpromoting sustainable approaches to managing resources. In the face of overfishing and deforestation, where Gandhi referred to âfood becoming Godâ, we see the conversion of capital assets into financial assets. A good example is cutting down a tree and not leaving that for subsequent generations.

Our aid budget is a shade under $2Â½ billion this year. That is the fifth increase in a row. Our overseas development aid to GNI ratio is 0.28 per cent, just higher than the OECD average. Breaking that down, there was a significant contribution to Indonesia for tsunami aid providing $500 million in grant funding, $500 million in highly concessional loans and $302 million this financial year. There is $492 million going to Papua New Guinea, part of the multiyear $1.1 billion enhanced cooperation program that will assist with consolidating the rule of law in that country and enhancing public sector development and access to basic services. To Pacific nations goes $463 millionâto the Solomon Islands goes $247 million of thatâand to East Asia goes $344 million, with current levels retained for East Timor. Aid to Iraq is $45 million over two years. There is $77 million going to Africa, $70 million of which is for HIV-AIDS programs; and there is $170 million in humanitarian relief and emergency aid, which, although not contributing directly to the millennium goals, plays a key role in helping people through the disastrous circumstances often found in Africa and Asia.

The Highly Indebted Poor Countries programâ$34.8 million over three yearsâis really a raft of assistance from the 20 or so wealthy countries whose economies add up to something like $20 trillion a year. With that program we can transition 38 struggling economies. Eighteen of the wealthy countries have already moved from the decision point through to finally being able to look at interim debt relief, reaching eventually a completion point where debts can be forgiven. But how do we actually map our way through what is a series of economiesâthe majority of them in Africaâwith average life expectancies of 42 years of age, with just one doctor for every 30,000 people, where one-third of the population will not live to the age of 35, with rising child mortality up to levels of 20 per cent and with less than $2 a day spent on health services? We know the money is going there and often not achieving the results we would like to see.

What are the reasons for the failure of aid so far? Jeffrey Sachs has described eight of them. These include the poverty trap. Willem de Kooning said the trouble with being poor is that it simply takes up all of your time. Scrounging from dawn to dusk to find a way to survive leaves no way to put away resources for when times are tough, let alone to export for an income. There is the fiscal trap of simply no tax collection with overhanging debt. There is corruption, combined with state failure. The other reasons include geography, geopolitical issues like trade barriers and embargoes, religious and cultural factors that prevent women from engaging in a community or an economy, the complete lack of innovation where poverty rules supreme so that two to three per cent of an economy cannot be dedicated to driving new ideas from patentingâ98 per cent of all patents rest with just a handful of countriesâand demographics where poverty brings up to five or six children per mother, making it extremely difficult to deliver forms of aid where population is expanding rapidly.

What we need to do is stop and thinkânot so much about what we are prepared to give and then be dismayed when it does not work but more about what it will take to begin to address the problem. We need to identify low-cost, proven interventions that can sustainably raise the standard of living and give economic opportunities to the 1.1 billion people who live in abject poverty. Keep in mind that, of the $76 billion of aid given last year, $16 billion went to middle-income countries, $11 billion went in reverse flows paying off debt, $6 billion was actually debt relief, $12 billion was in direct government support to keep the wheels turning and $19 billion was paid to consultants who simply finished their work and returned to their home countries. Of that $76 billion, just 16 per cent actually went to addressing extreme poverty and supporting the basic needs in communities in these countries.

There is a need to raise the aid from 77c a day to around $1.08. It does not seem like much. One benefit of being poor is that sometimes it does not take much to improve your situation substantially. Today let us define a basic packageâas Geoffrey Sax has done in his recent publication. For a population, just $10 a head can allow fields to lie fallow, pay for fertilisers, triple agricultural output and stave off poverty, as we have seen in Asia more successfully than in Africa. For another $10 per person, a medical clinic can be staffed with a doctor, with preventative health and immunisations provided. For another $10 per person, there can be an off-grid generator with batteries in homes and the chance of a cheap light bulb to provide light in households. For another $5 per person there can be sanitation, water, bores and 10 conveniently located taps in communities. For another $5, obviously amortised over some period, there can be a truck for a village, modern fuels for schools, somewhere to store grain and a few mobile phones to connect villages so that they can have access to information like prices for their products. That amounts to around $US70 a day.

Poverty has been likened to a crime you have never committed. That is why it is disappointing that we sometimes hear comments such as âAustralia has fallen tragically short in matching its action to rhetoricâ, because we do know that the overseas aid program has been maintained at a reasonably sustainable level. There were drops during the first two years of the Hawke governmentâover that period it fell by a third. It is now recovering to around 0.28 per cent, but we do know a little about being indebted, because the opposition left this country as a highly indebted rich country. It does not take much to know that $90 billion would go a long way in the developing world. In fact, with the $90 billion of Australian debt we could well have paid for the fertilisers, the medical clinic, the generators, the sanitation, the springs, the bores, the taps, the trucks, the modern fuels and storage and handling for all of those 1.1 billion people living in extreme poverty worldwide and still have change left over for a couple of extra continents. That is the purchasing power of the debt that Australia was left with. It is only through responsible domestic policy that that can be avoided and Australia can become a true friend of the highly indebted economies. That will leave Australia not $90 billion behind but in a position to be able to look after the indebted countries that, today, look to us for support. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy grievance concerns the construction and location of telecommunications towers within my electorate of Lowe, but it also has relevance right across Australia. As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, the Telecommunications (Low-Impact Facilities) Determination was made in 1997 for the purpose of determining whether certain telecommunications facilities fall within the definition of âlow impactâ. The term âlow-impact facilitiesâ defines a range of telecommunications facilities that are likely to have an impact on the amenity of an area. As such, the purpose of the determination is not what one may thinkâthat is, to protect persons from any potential harmful effects of electromagnetic radiation. In short, the determination is an amenity instrument not unlike those environmental factors that are found as prescribed matters for determination for a development application under section 79C of the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979.

speech.para: I wish to raise the issue of environmental impact and the interphase between the Commonwealth and New South Wales state laws that is directly related to this environmental impact. In particular, I raise an issue that I have raised many times in the House in the past: gap analysis in the Commonwealth-state laws interphase. What is being increasingly observed throughout New South Wales is that there is a gap in the effective protection afforded by the combined effects of environmental instruments when the Commonwealth and state laws are read together. In particular, the determination of whether a facility is low impact or not does not overcome the fact that constitutional law precludes a matter being considered by a state or territory government that falls within the purview of Commonwealth law and vice versa.

In this case, when a facility is determined to be a low-impact facility, the effect of this finding places the construction of a low-impact facility outside the purview of the state or territory planning laws, such as the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act. This is a matter that has received considerable attention in the states and territories as well as within the various land and environment courts and related jurisdictions. In particular, the issue of whether state or territory planning and related laws may be nonetheless applicable to a facility that is determined to be of low impact is a considerable issue that has received much commentary. When considering the merits of the dual application of both state and territory planning law as well as Commonwealth telecommunications law, it is salient today to review the policy intent of these laws.

Firstly, members of the House will be aware that the policy intent of the Commonwealth Telecommunications (Low-Impact Facilities) Determination is primarily one of ameliorating amenity impacts. The purpose of this determination is not to prevent the effects of harmful long-term determination as one might expect; it is simply to reduce the visual and other aesthetic impacts of the telecommunication facility. When one reads the telecommunications determination, one gets the distinct impression that the legislatorâs intent is more concerned about the visual impactâthe colour, size and blending in with the surroundingsârather than any potential harmful emissions of radiation or health risks and other related injuries from long-term exposure to radiation.

This in turn raises the broader planning of same and other environmental laws. As members of the House are also aware, environmental laws are largely the purview of the residual constitutional jurisdiction of the states and territories. This residual jurisdiction includes those powers over planning, environment, heritage and other laws directly relevant to the policy objects of the determination. However, to add confusion to this matter, the Howard government has repeatedly made laws which trammel policy areas, which has the effect of making the administration of laws very muddy indeed. In particular, the use of Commonwealth constitutional telecommunications powers for the making of what is ultimately a determination relating to amenity is, I believe, very misplaced legislation.

The issue of amenity is not isolated in the policy bandwidth of environmental law and, for this reason, is better placed in Commonwealth and state environmental and planning laws; so too is the issue of âknocking outâ the application of well-established state and territory planning and environmental laws on a constitutional technicality where a facility is determined to be âlow impactâ. This is equally a negative use of Commonwealth law, deliberately designed by administrative construction to exclude the application of state and territory laws for the purpose of regulating these so-called âlow-impact facilitiesâ which, but for the Commonwealth telecommunications determination, would be âworksâ within the meaning of state planning law and, hence, subject to development approval.

Significantly, this is the very purpose of the New South Wales planning law. A critical part of the New South Wales planning law is the application of the precautionary principle, which I have spoken about a number of times in this place and which is enshrined in New South Wales legislation such as the Protection of the Environment Administration Act at section 6. It is legislation such as this which is excluded by a deliberate act of obfuscation in the making of this determination. The precautionary principle states that, where there is a risk of foreseeable, non-negligible risk of harm, then lack of full scientific certainty ought not be used as a pretext to justify the postponement of ameliorative measures to mitigate that harm.

For this reason, I call upon the Commonwealth government to agree that telecommunications towers construction be subject to full planning and development laws of the states and territories such that telecommunications towers be subject to development assessment. In doing so, the long-suffering people of my electorate, and indeed Sydney and right across Australia and elsewhere, who are driven to despair when they see telecommunications and mobile phone towers being constructed literally over their heads will have some redress to fairer and more equitable assessment of the size and location of these notorious towers.

Millions of Australians rely on their mobile phones and need adequate mobile phone coverage. While Commonwealth communications law has recently forced mobile phone companies to at least inform local councils and nearby residents when they install so-called âlow-impactâ facilities, I believe this does not go far enough. Regardless of assurances from phone companies regarding their safety, local residents and businesses deserve the right to object to the installation of any tower on health or environmental grounds. The government should act to stop mobile phone companies treating local residents with contempt, allow complaints to be heard before these towers appear and force mobile phone companies to co-locate these âlow-impactâ facilities at every opportunity.

talk.start.para: âIt is my privilege to speak today and to report to the House on some very interesting developments that have been happening in the great ongoing campaign to encourage the recycling of water in the Lockyer Valley and in the area of my electorate in south-east Queensland. This is something that I am very keen on, as I know other members areâI think including you, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams. We have been enthused over the years by the potential of projects for this region to use all or at least a large proportion of that great quantity of water coming out of the area of Brisbane, Ipswich and the Gold Coast for purposes other than just dumping it into the sea, with the opportunity to be able to increase agriculture in our region and to be able to recycle that water for all kinds of purposes.

speech.para: I am naturally very interested in the potential for agricultural use. But this is not something that is important just from a farmerâs viewpoint; it is something that is absolutely important for everyone who lives in south-east Queensland. One thing that is bleedingly obvious is that the rate of growth in south-east Queensland is phenomenal. If we do not take great steps to preserve the environment of our south-east Queensland region, we run the risk of all the beautiful green belt, particularly through the Lockyer Valley, out west of Ipswich and right the way out to Toowoomba, disappearing under housing in the same way that the Redlands area has disappeared under housing over the years.

We do not want that. There are ample areas of outcropping hills and locations like that where urban development can occur, but we need to keep that beautiful green belt available for farming. In order to make it suitable for farming, we have to making farming in those areas profitable. We are not talking about a margin call here; it has to be very profitable because, if it is not, farmers will not have sufficient incentive to want to continue farming. It will be a much easier option to just subdivide, and there goes the ballgame.

At the weekend I attended a meeting that I thought at last showed that we are starting to make real progress in regard to recycled water.
