On this occasion I would like to pay credit to the effort now being put in by the state government. A little while ago the state government commented, âIf you want to be an agricultural user in the Lockyer Valley, perhaps we would look at selling you water out of Wivenhoeââthat is, water out of the drinking supply for Brisbane. Obviously, that was never going to happen. The state government appear to have come on board with the idea of recycling. They have got behind a very positive effort put in by the Ipswich City Council to explore options to recycle water out of Ipswich and the Oxley waste treatment centres, to take it to industry and to commercial users and, at the end of it all, to make that water available for agricultural use in our region.

It is important that we get that water to the farmers. They have been living a hand-to-mouth existence. Right now they are celebrating the lovely soaking rain that has fallen in that areaâbut, my God, rain is such a rare occasion that all it does is serve to underline just how tenuous the lifestyle of farmers currently is. To have rain these days is merely a reminder of how often they have not had rain. For that region we need something much better, and that comes in the form of recycled water. If we can get that water to the farmersâwater that is available when they turn on the tap, that goes to their crops, it can guarantee their livelihoodâthey can plan with real certainty to have a crop next time to market. It means that they can be sure about the quality of their crop. This is significant.

This meeting was under the auspices of the Lockyer Water Users Forum, ably headed up by Linton Brimblecombe and held in the Rosewood shire hall. Representatives of Enhance Management and the Moreton Rural Financial Counselling Serviceâwhich included Peter Corey and Rod Menziesâand Jim Kelly from ARRIS Management also attended. Those players are significant. Enhance Management are well known in Queensland because they are good at conducting surveys and at getting community feedback and that kind of thing. They are ideally located to be able to carry the message on recycled water back to the state government.

Jim Kelly is from Adelaide University. He is an expert in recycled water issues and he has been involved in the Virginia water scheme in South Australia for many years. His understanding of recycled water issues across the world is absolutely up to date. He is also an inspirational speaker, and he was very good at this meeting. It was attended by farmers from across the regionâthe people who are the potential users of this water, many of whom had their doubts and concernsâwho were looking to have some of those concerns answered. I think they were answered in spades, not only by the words from Jim Kelly but also by the figures given by Rod Menzies and Peter Corey. They gave an analysis of farming operations that I think just blew the minds of the people there. If you are used to existing on a subsistence levelâthe sort of hand-to-mouth existence of many of these farmers with small holdings who are currently experiencing the vagaries of poor rainfall and increasing salinityâissues such as this and the kinds of figures that came from Rod and from Peter on this occasion were spectacular.

With the support of the state government and the Ipswich City Council, these gentlemen have gone out and spoken to 50 different farming businesses across the Lockyer, Bremer and Warrill valley regions. They have gone to farmers in those areas and they have looked carefully at their farm businesses and at what could happen if those farms were moved from their current tenuous existence onto recycled water. The first thing that people ask is: âHow much have we got to pay for this water? How much is it going to cost us?â That is their overwhelming concern. Many of the people who are directly affected by this problem do not look deeper into the question of what the salinity of this water is compared to the kind of water they are currently surviving on. If you have water with a better salinity, does that mean that you can grow better crops? I can tell you that it certainly does mean that.

The bottom line from the figures given at this meeting was very interesting. Many of the farmers in my region have said: âWe cannot afford to pay more than $150 a megalitre for this water. We absolutely cannot; that is it. That is the bottom line.â The number that they have been talking about again and again is $150 a megalitre. Rod Menzies and Peter Corey are very good gents. These are guys who have for many years spent their time living cheek-by-jowl with local farmers, reviewing their farming operations and trying to offer them pointers on how to improve their operations. These guys are very well respected.

After their study of 50 different farms in this region to determine just what can be done with recycled water, they told the meeting yesterday that, assuming a price of $450 a megalitreâthat is the figure for an average farm in our areaâit was still possible for the gross profit margin to be exactly the same. That is spectacular. That was mind-numbing as far as the local farmers were concerned. It is something that beggars belief for them. The idea that you could afford to pay that much and still have a good level of profitability had not occurred to them in the past, but it shows the reality of the situation. It shows the great potential that lies ahead.

These meetings are occurring, because we are looking at the question of recycled water and we are looking at it seriously, now with the support of the state and with the support of Ipswich City Council. We are looking at it very closely. Throughout this week there will be a series of these shed meetings, where the findings of this research into farming profitability and the findings in relation to the health and safety standards that relate to recycled water will be relayed back to all these farmers, one after the other, throughout our region. At the end of it all we are seeking a commitment from people to take up the cause of recycled water, to look very closely at their operations and to put up their hands and be prepared to support the move to recycled water. It certainly represents the future of farming in our area and, in my view, it represents the future of our region because without it a lot of the very positive things we currently have in south-east Queensland will be lost.

talk.start.para: âI wish to bring to the attention of the House the plight of a constituent of mine, Mr Barry Tracy of Bouldercombe near Rockhampton. Mr Tracy worked for over 10 years for John Shiemer Earthmoving but during that time his employer did not pay Barryâs superannuation levy. Barry and his wife, Clare, contacted my office back in October 2004 and my staff put the Tracys in contact with the Australian Taxation Office.

speech.para: As it turned out, the Tracys tax agent had, in fact, already contacted the tax office about the matter back on 8 July 2004 when the agent lodged a complaint regarding John Shiemer Earthmovingâs non-payments of Barryâs entitlements under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. Mr Tracy himself had raised the matter of non-payment of superannuation with the ATO as far back as 15 September 2003.

An amount of $12,622.65 owing to Mr Tracy was recovered from the employer in May 2004. At this point in the story, it is three cheers all around for the tax office in achieving that. However, it goes downhill from there for the tax office. This moneyâthe $12,000-oddâhas been held by the tax office since May 2004 and, despite the best efforts of all concerned, the tax office will not forward this money to Mr Tracyâs superannuation fund so that Mr Tracy, who has now retired, can access the money.

The frustration felt by Mr and Mrs Tracy has been exacerbated by the fact that all of their dealings with the ATO have had to be conducted over the telephone. This government closed the ATO office in Rockhampton, so it is no longer possible for the taxpayers of Central Queensland to go to their local tax office and sort their problems out face to face. The question is: where has this money been for the past year? In its media release of 30 July 2004, the ATO advised:

quote.para: A new computer system was put in place last Decemberâ

speech.para: that is, December 2003â

quote.para: to administer the new quarterly Super Guarantee legislation and to make direct payments to super funds of employee entitlements. ... We have had problems with the new system that have caused delays, particularly with cases involving unpaid entitlements from past years. We are working to rectify the systems problems as quickly as possible.

speech.para: The ATO introduced a new computer system in December 2003 and now in June 2005, nearly two years later, the system is still not working, and it is my constituent who is caught in the middle. The Tracys have spoken to the ATO on a fortnightly basis without any success. My concern is: just how many other people like Barry Tracy are waiting for the ATO to get its system right before they receive the superannuation money that is rightfully theirs? One has to ask: what would happen if a major private institution, like a bank, had a computer system that did not work two years after installation? You just could not imagine it. Meanwhile, Mr Tracy is struggling to survive on a reduced pension. Centrelink have advised that, as Mr Tracy has some unused super, he is not entitled to the full pension. But of course, as I have just spelled out, it is not Mr Tracy but the Australian Taxation Office which is holding his moneyâand has been since May 2004.

Mr and Mrs Tracy have been advised on a number of occasions that the money is on its way, only to be disappointed every time. Mr Tracy was told in May this year that the money would be available to him in June. But Mr and Mrs Tracy have heard it all before so were not too disappointed when they received a call on 15 June, just last week, to be told that the money would not now come through until the end of July. On hearing the story of Mr and Mrs Tracy, how can anyone have confidence in the ATO? It is my intention to continue to pursue this matter until Barry and Clare Tracy receive their money from the tax office with every cent of interest that is owing to them as a result of this debacle.

I would also like to use this time today to raise another issue of concern to the residents in Capricornia. It relates to the possible use of depleted uranium, which has come into sharp focus at this time when 17,000 US and Australian troops are engaged in military exercises on our doorstep at Shoalwater Bay in Central Queensland. There is a broad recognition in this country of the strategic importance of Shoalwater Bay in building Australiaâs defence capability and the goal of interoperability with the United States forces. However, there is another equally important aspect of Shoalwater Bay and one that is particularly close to the heart of those of us fortunate enough to live within its reach. Shoalwater Bay is a natural treasure of immense beauty and environmental significance. For people living in Central Queensland, its protection has to be paramount and no shortcuts or âsheâll be right mateâ assurances can be good enough when questions of possible environmental degradation are raised.

There are a number of areas of concern when it comes to the environmental impact of military exercises on Shoalwater Bay and the land and sea adjacent to it. Concerns raised with me include the effect of marine sonar technology on marine mammals, including whales and dugong, and the general threat of land and water contamination. However, as more and more evidence emerges about the use of depleted uranium by the US military in both the Gulf War and the current Iraq war, and its potentially disastrous effects on Iraqi civilians and Defence Force personnel, alarm bells have been ringing in Central Queensland.

Residents are asking: âDo we really know what weapons have been used at Shoalwater Bay and what steps have been taken to ensure there is no contamination left behind?â The Citizens Against Depleted Uranium Group based on the Capricorn Coast, effectively in Shoalwater Bayâs backyard, has started asking those questions and educating the community about the dangers of depleted uranium. Well might they be concerned. There is a wealth of material about depleted uranium and its effects on humans and the environment. The following quote comes from the International Depleted Uranium Study Team:

quote.para: Depleted uranium is the radioactive and highly toxic waste product that remains after natural uranium metal has been put through the âenrichmentâ process. The enriched uranium is used by the military and nuclear industries. The material left over is the depleted uranium.

Depleted uranium is most commonly used in the military for armour plating for tanks and also for projectiles designed to penetrate heavy armour. It is also the basis of the bunker buster bombs used in the âShock and Aweâ campaign against Baghdad in 2003.

In addition to its density depleted uranium is a pyrophoric metal. Thus when a projectile made of DU strikes a heavily armoured tank the force of impact causes the DU to ignite and burn at such an intense temperature that the projectile literally melts its way through the armour.

In the process of this disintegration an aerosol of radioactive particles is produced. These can be inhaled and remain in the body for decades. In the same way depleted uranium can contaminate the air, soil and water around the explosion.

speech.para: In the face of such sobering information coming out about these weapons, I believe it is quite reasonable for my constituents to be asking for more than just the bland assurances they have received so far from the Minister for Defence. As people who live in the shadow of Shoalwater Bay, who want to protect their families and their unique environment, they are asking for proof that they have nothing to fear. Although the Minister for Defence is on record as ruling out the use of depleted uranium in the current joint training exercise, Talisman Sabre 2005, that still leaves open the question of previous use at Shoalwater Bay. Senator Chris Evans asked that question of the minister, Senator Hill, in 2003, and his answers do not contain the kind of proof that my constituents require. Senator Evans asked:

quote.para: Is the United States military permitted to transport munitions containing depleted uranium on Australian soil or within Australian waters?

speech.para: The minister answered simply: âYes.â Senator Evans also asked:

quote.para: Have munitions containing depleted uranium ever been used in exercises within Australia; if so, can a list be provided of the occasions on which such munitions were used, including the nature of the exercises?

speech.para: The ministerâs answer was:

quote.para: The ADF and its contractors have reviewed documents and data pertaining to the weapons used on Australian Training Areas and any requests from foreign forces for the use of depleted uranium munitions. No evidence of depleted uranium ammunition being used on Australian Training Areas was found. There are no available records of exact times and locations at which depleted uranium munitions were expended at sea.

speech.para: My constituents ask for more than that. I have a great deal of respect for the way this group of community minded people, the Citizens Against Depleted Uranium, have gone about their campaign. They are passionate about their cause but they have not sought to further it by grandstanding or through disruption. Instead, they have thoroughly researched the issue and have put forward five legitimate and reasonable requests to the government. They have put those forward in a letter to Senator Hill and I support them in making those requests. I ask the minister to respond by, among other things, agreeing to the testing of Shoalwater Bay for the use of depleted uranium and by giving a guarantee that weapons containing depleted uranium will not be used in Shoalwater Bay in the future.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr JOHN COBB

talk.start.para: âThe Australian governmentâs industrial relations proposals are quite obviously being welcomed by businesses large and small right around Australia. The proposals are welcome because businesses need them. They need them in order to start businesses, to have confidence in putting people on and to spend money on training those people. They are very happy about what this government is going to do for a lot of reasons, not the least of which is the fact that there is going to be a fairer system that will guarantee increased employment around Australia and maintain the rights of workers everywhere.

speech.para: I can understand that the Labor Party would try to put a negative spin on this. After all, we are talking about their masters, the union leaders. We are talking about what they consider their core constituency, which is threatened with being irrelevant. As a party that is irrelevant of course they would oppose us and support the union leadership, but there is an enormous deception in the message being put out. The campaign being run by both the opposition and the unions is almost totally dishonest. They are trying to create division through fearâby misrepresentation, by making people believe their jobs are under threat and by making people believe that they will have no rights and will not be able to be represented. That is all totally untrue, as any fair-minded person who looks at the proposals would have to agree. But we are not dealing with people who are fair-minded. We are not, in this caseâespecially with what I am going to talk about this afternoonâdealing with people who have any intention of being fair-minded.

It is a factâand this has been consistently pointed out and is there for anybody to readâthat workers will still have the right, should they wish to do so, to be represented by a unionâto be represented by a collective voiceâand to have their conditions represented by a union or by a collective voice. They will have the right to have a unionist sitting down with them at any stage, should they wish to negotiate with their employer. They will also have the right, I am very proud to say, to negotiate on their own behalf or have someone help them do that. A workplace agreement will allow them to do that, be they miners, farm workers or teachers. Along with various other sectors the teachers union, the most vocal of all, are being totally dishonest when they say that certain things are threatened here and that we are not going to have teachers in places like Dubbo and Broken Hill. They are being totally dishonest, because if anybody wishes to take advantage of their own special skills, dedication to their work, honesty and ability to put more in than anybody else, they can take advantage of that under a workplace agreement.

It stuns me that anybodyâthe member for Murray-Darling or any union leaderâwould want to deny anyone who is or is not a member of their organisation the ability to sit down and negotiate one on one with an employer to improve their conditions. I find that incredible. It would, I guess, be amusing were it not for the fact that it is so frightening that people have far more concern about their union power and about having power over others than they are about helping those people help themselves.

As I said, employees can negotiate an Australian workplace agreement on their own, they can have someone do it for them or they can be represented collectively by a union or by somebody else. That is their choice. That is what these new proposals for industrial relations in Australia are about: choice and certainty for business. I know a lot of young people who would love to start their own businesses but who are simply not going to do it under current circumstances.

Leaving aside the fact that there will be recourse to the courts, as there is in any normal situation, why would any employerâand I guess I am referring here to some of the misconceptions and dishonest statements being put out by members of the opposition and union leaders when they talk about how many people are going to be unfairly dismissedâwant to sack someone for no good reason when they have spent the time and money that they must spend in order to train a person for a position today? There are almost no positions that do not have some kind of specialisation and that do not require some kind of training. Why would anybody want to go to the cost that that involves and then sack a person for no good reason? Suggesting that only shows that theyâthe opposition, union leaders and particularly the member for Murray-Darlingâhave absolutely no conception of the costs of running a business and the hassles of changing employees. Why in heavenâs name would anybody have any desire to do that for no good reason?

The member for Murray-Darling in the state government has now decided to enter the industrial relations debate in Broken Hill with a sensational headline predicting devastation for small business. It would be funny if it were not so serious. The Broken Hill Chamber of Commerce has totally rejected the proposition that the governmentâs measures will be devastating for business and it has rejected the state memberâs comments about all the extra work businesses will have to do. In fact, exactly the opposite is the truth. It will be much simpler. One industrial relations system throughout Australia is hardly going to make things more complexâobviously, the reverse will be true.

To try to portray the situation as being that small business in particularâand to some extent large businessâis in trouble with this legislation is laughable in Broken Hill, as it is elsewhere. I think the chamber of commerce has made it plain that the member for Murray-Darling is certainly not speaking for themâcertainly not on this issue anyway. There is no fear about this legislation among Broken Hill businesses. Who would you believe in this debate? The member for Murray-Darling more than anything else is trying to deflect criticism from himself and the state government he is a member of. That government is being criticised because of its withdrawal from drought support; because of the extra tax it is imposing on clubs in New South Wales, a tax the member for Murray-Darling is having trouble explaining; because of the transport troubles it is inânot supporting branch lines, taking money away from roads and from rail and spending it all in Sydney and then going broke, which they obviously are and having a budget deficit, which they obviously have. Why would the member for Murray-Darling be trying to make headlines out of this issue before us tonight? Simply because he and his government are in terrible trouble and have obviously no intention of doing anything for country New South Wales. He is trying, through fear and dishonesty, to pull down a system that business all over Australia wants and that will, in effect, create competition.

We are a government which has brought unemployment to record low levels right around this country. I think it is now about 29 years since we had unemployment at the current low level. The government is dedicated to economic prosperity for this country and to low unemploymentâwhich we have. The opposition, the member for Murray-Darling and the union leaders probably do not understand competition. If they understood competition, they would realise that the more competition there is for jobs the more employers will pay to have the right peopleânaturally, because they have to. That is what competition means. Whether it is employers looking for good employees, employees looking for good employers or simply a matter of reducing prices, competition delivers results to the people of Australia.

If they want to try to make out that this legislation is a problem, let them look to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, where quite obviously it is the reverse. It is simple: wages are good and conditions are good. Long service leave, minimum wages and superannuation are all being safeguarded by these proposals. For anybody who thinks that this coalition government is not about being there for everybody and especially for the workers of Australia, how is it that under this government real wages have gone up by 14 per cent? (Time expired)

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr PYNE

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the amendment be agreed to.

speech.para: The National Security Information Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 adds another dimension to the current protections for security-sensitive information. Late last year the parliament passed the National Security Information (Criminal Proceedings) Act to protect information that may affect our national security if disclosed in federal criminal proceedings. That legislation was the subject of review by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The government adopted several recommendations of that committee and made amendments to the legislation that were supported by the parliament after robust debate. The regime for protecting classified material in criminal proceedings is the product of that extensive scrutiny and debate. It is appropriate therefore that the regime for protecting sensitive information in civil proceedings resembles, as far as possible, the arrangements previously endorsed by the parliament. That is the purpose of this bill, and I am confident that the purpose has been achieved.

The bill was amended in the other chamber to provide criteria for courts to consider when considering whether to exercise the stay provision in the bill. The amendment was an opposition amendment that the government was prepared to consider and promptly accept in the spirit of cooperation and expediency. I encourage the members opposite to continue to work constructively with the government to develop workable solutions to policy challenges rather than referring this responsibility to a Senate committee as a matter of habit.

We will be unable to assess the full impact of the new arrangements for managing national security information in court proceedings until we see them in practice. That is why the government has undertaken to conduct a departmental review of the legislation and to provide a report to each house of parliament on the operation of the act after the end of three years from the date of the legislationâs commencement. The National Security Information Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 adds another dimension to the current protections for security-sensitive information. I commend the bill, as amended by the Senate, to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports the amendment to the National Security Information Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. I think it is fair to say, without claiming credit, it has its genesis in a proposal that we put to the government in a cooperative senseâbut, again, having regard to recommendations from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It is almost like clockwork that when we do refer a bill to a committeeâand, in particular, quite complex national security legislationâthe current Attorney-General will say that it is a demonstration that we are prevaricating or weak on national security. That is invariably proved to be a hollow accusation, because invariably the committee comes back with sensible proposals. Some people may say it is wishful thinking on my part and others may say it is arrogance in predicting dangers for the government, but if the government assume that with a Senate majority from 1 July they will be the exclusive holders of wisdom in framing legislation then they will leave themselves open, at the very least, to a charge of arrogance and, at a more severe level, to a fall by way of an error or in not being connected with public opinion.

speech.para: Our Senate committee system has been particularly effective because of a reasonable balance of membership, but I think the parliamentary committee system as a whole is really an unsung asset of the federal parliament. I know that some of my most fruitful years in the parliament have been spent participating in the committee system. Contrary to popular media, there is a lot of talent in the federal parliament both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. Contrary to public opinion and the popular media there is a lot of goodwill and determination to try to achieve legislation that is in the national interest, as opposed to simply party-political interests. While there was a clear indication from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing that the Attorney-General has been somewhat annoyed when these references to committees have occurred, where we can we have tried to expedite the committee process so that reports could be handed down without unduly delaying the legislative process. But people should not underestimate or devalue the contribution made by the committees.

In particular, in briefly addressing the issues in this case, the primary national security information legislation applying to criminal proceedings was in some ways more significantâwhether or not someone went to jailâbut in other ways it was easier to deal with because ultimately we kept the discretion of the actual trial court to govern the outcome of the proceedings and, in particular, to determine the restriction on the admissibility or form in which national security-sensitive information was to be admitted. Both sides of parliament preserved the full powers of the court, including the ability of the court to stay those proceedings.

As a number of experts who have been referred to in the Senate mentioned in their evidence to the committeeâagain, in the committee processâthat logic is not always convenient or practical in a civil proceeding because you may in fact be staying a proceeding by a citizen against a government and actually depriving a citizen of their rights. This amendment essentially gives some guidance to the court that, before they stay a proceeding, for instance, they should have regard to both the costs incurred by the litigant up to that stage and whether their order would deprive the litigantâand I am not using the precise wordsâof a likely or potential remedy. And there is a catch-all in the amendment of âany other matter the court considers relevantâ. The process was not lacking in merit. A reasonable outcome occurred, and we believe the legislation is better for having gone to the committee. A sensible proposal, ultimately refined with the expertise of the government, has been put forward which we are happy to accept and agree to as members of the opposition.

talk.start.para: (Hon. DGH Adams)âThe question is that the amendment be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT AMENDMENT (EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES RELIEF PAYMENT) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 June, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 amends the Farm Household Support Act 1992 to give effect to some of the measures outlined in the 2005 drought assistance package announced by the Prime Minister. The major elements of the governmentâs package include more generous exceptional circumstances interest rate subsidies, with a revised assets testâand that measure accounts for $196.3 millionâa more generous income test for EC relief payments of $49.3 million; additional counselling and support services, totalling $8.98 million; a second round of Envirofund grants of $10 million, taken from existing appropriations; an extension of the streamlined reassessment process for those EC declared areas nearing the end of their second year of assistance and a review by the National Rural Advisory Council of areas not recommended for EC extension over the past year; and $3 million for the CWA. Most of the changes announced by the government can be made by ministerial direction, but this piece of legislation is necessary to provide for changes to the income test for EC relief payments. It provides an exemption of up to $10,000 from off-farm wages and salaries to a person and their partner as of 1 July 2005, and it also provides that in future a person seeking exceptional circumstances relief payments will make an application directly to Centrelink instead of to a state or territory rural adjustment authority.

speech.para: Labor welcomes the measures announced by the Prime Minister on 30 May and welcomes the measures that are included in this piece of legislation. However, we are disappointed that it has taken so long for the government to make even this tentative start at reforming and improving drought policy. It is fair to ask why it has taken the government 10 years to come to this position. Many of the criticisms of drought policy have been around for many years, yet it has taken this long into the governmentâs several terms of office for the government to come to grips with some of the more substantial criticisms of its administration of drought policy. I make the point which I have made in previous debates: the government can find $6 million for useless advertising in the lead-up to an electionâindeed, that $6 million in the agriculture sector was part of a $100 million advertising package in place before the electionâand it can find $1 billion for a war in Iraq, yet it cannot get its drought policy right.

This is not the only major area of policy neglect we have seen from this minister and from this government. We can all remember the live exports debacle and the fact that the minister almost single-handedly brought the trade to its knees as a result of his neglect and incompetence. Of course, we have the current shambles in quarantine policyâa similar result of the ministerâs neglect. In that particular instance, we had legal actions by a major producer body, a trading mess and a scathing legal judgment on the administration of Australiaâs quarantine policy. Now we have substantial criticisms of the governmentâs administration of drought policy. The Auditor-General has recently issued a report that contains scathing criticism of the Howard governmentâs performance in relation to drought. I am pleased to see in the chamber the honourable member for Lyons, who will accompany me in this debate, and the honourable member for Ballarat. They have some very important points that they want to make about the administration of drought policy in this country.
In light of those criticisms, I move:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its:

item.para: failure to take on board in a timely way the warnings of the CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorologyâs National Climate Centre and the Queensland Climate Centre that the last five years have been among the driest on record and that there is no evidence that the situation is likely to improve;
failure to fund the proposed CRC for Climate Risk Technologies;
decision to scrap the Drought Investment Allowance;
failure to adequately fund drought relief in this yearâs budget;
failure to provide long term financial certainty for the Rural Financial Counselling Service;

failure to implement a significant part of the May 2002 agreement between the Commonwealth and all States and Territories for administrative reforms to drought relief aimed at getting help to farmers faster and with less red tape; and
failure to provide any measure within the Exceptional Circumstances arrangements that would assist farmers to make a realistic economic assessment of their long term futureâ.

speech.para: I understand that the honourable member for Lyons will be seconding that second reading amendment in the context of this debate. As I pointed out, the Auditor-General has recently issued a report that contains scathing criticism of the Howard governmentâs performance in relation to drought. It is especially critical of the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestryâs department in its contingency planning for and response to drought. The Auditor found:

quote.para: The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF) did not have a specific preparedness or contingency plan for drought, notwithstanding previous recommendations made by a Taskforce of Australian and State and Territory Government officials to this effect.

speech.para: I find it incomprehensible and beyond belief that in 2005 the Auditor-General could make this sort of conclusion about the ministerâs department and the administration of drought policy in this country. It is a damning indictment of the ministerâs administration of his portfolio area that in a country as dry as Australia, where droughts are common, he has made no contingency plans for dealing with drought.
The Auditor also found that while the department did identify risks and problems associated with the delivery of EC assistance, there were:

quote.para: ... no specific treatment strategies identified, corresponding to these risks. Nor did risk plans identify the possibility that substantial additional measures might be needed ...

speech.para: So we had 45 per cent of Australia drought declared and 85 per cent of one of Australiaâs most important agriculture producing states, New South Wales, had been drought declared for several years, and the Auditor says, ânor did any plans identify the possibility that substantial additional measures might be needed.â That was reflected in the budget measures that the government brought down. It is no wonder that the minister seriously underestimated the impact of the drought in this yearâs departmental budget. His department had no plans and did not even understand that additional measures might be needed.

The Auditor also found that there was no whole-of-government implementation plan and no integrated communication strategy. It is little wonder that the Auditor came to that conclusion, because the minister has gone out of his way to abuse the state governments who have been involved in the front line in assisting farmers to cope with drought. He also found serious problems in documentation by the department. There were gaps in some documentation on files and the maps used for EC declarations did not line up with the areas described in press releases announcing EC assistance. Can you believe that in 2005, after 10 years of this governmentâs administration of drought policy, the Auditor could come up with these sorts of substantial criticisms? This is a scathing indictment of the Howard governmentâs administration of drought policy in this country.

Despite the bleating by members opposite on how much the government has allocated to drought, allocation is one thing; giving farmers access to the funds is another. We see this in various programs that this government administers in the agriculture sector. From sugar to drought, the government makes great play of the amount of money that it allocates. Some years down the line, when you examine exactly what has been accessed, you will find that it is a different story altogether. No wonder the Auditor found that many farmers find the whole process of applying for drought assistance very confusing. The minister has presided over serious failures in the administration of drought policy by his department. It seems that under the Howard government the delivery of drought assistance has been characterised by poor planning and poor administration. They are not my words but the conclusions of the Auditor-General.

When I view this package, there is one particular area where I am pleased to see a small increase in the funding. It is the funding for the Rural Financial Counselling Service, which was given additional funding as part of this package. The Rural Financial Counselling Service provides a wonderful service on very limited resources in very trying conditions. The additional funding is welcomed, but it does not address the concerns of the service itself or of farmer organisations about the long-term viability of this service. It is time that the government bit the bullet and announced secure, long-term funding for this service at a level that will allow counsellors to get on with the job of helping farm families and communities, without having to worry about the long-term future of the service and going to the government every year with a begging bowl, so that the basic expertise and infrastructure can be kept in place to meet contingencies such as prolonged drought.

I am also concerned that there is nothing in the exceptional circumstances arrangements that would help farm families complete a thorough assessment of the long-term, ongoing viability of the enterprise. I am thinking of the sort of assistance that is currently available under the Farm Help program to access the service of a professional accountant skilled in assessing farm businesses and assisting with forward planning. There would be considerable benefit in allowing farmers to access this sort of assistance at a much earlier stage than is available under current arrangements.

The measures announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on 30 May in the main dealt with making it a bit easier for farmers to access drought relief once an area has been drought declared. It is disappointing to me that the government has not also gone back a step and reviewed the measures in place to help farmers prepare for the eventuality of drought. The government has placed great store in the Farm Management Deposits Scheme as the centrepiece of its efforts to help farmers prepare for drought. In fact, the agriculture minister mentioned the Farm Management Deposits scheme in his press release of 30 May 2005, when he announced the package that we are discussing here today. This is a very important scheme that has proven invaluable for many farm families as they have struggled through the recent dry years.

talk.start.para: âCorrect.

âCorrect, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has stated. But it is a bit rich for the parliamentary secretary, the minister and the government to claim credit for the scheme. The scheme is in many important respects the successor to the arrangements that operated under the former Labor government from at least 1992. These arrangements included the Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme and the Farm Management Bond Scheme as well as a provision for tax averaging. The Farm Management Deposits scheme was not a new initiative by the Howard government but basically a rebadging of Labor policy. We need to get that very clear.

speech.para: The Howard government can rightly claim credit for two actions related to the ability of farmers to prepare for drought. It can claim credit for axing the drought investment allowance. Tax deductibility for investment in increased drought preparedness was introduced by the former Labor government to help farmers and give them more incentive to prepare their enterprises to cope with drought. In a very short-sighted decision in 1997, this important initiative was scrapped by the Howard government. It was none other than the current leader of The Nationals, John Anderson, who was agriculture minister in 1997, who axed this very important allowance.

The government can claim credit for another very short-sighted decision. Just before Christmas last year, the government decided to reject the proposal for a cooperative research centre for climate risk technologies. Such a CRC could have played an important role in helping farmers prepare much better for severe drought events. The primary focus of the proposed CRC was to have been to convert our understanding of Australiaâs complex climatic systems into easy-to-use products for farm businesses and rural communities to integrate into farm business catchment and regional planning. In this very dry continent of ours, this sort of research is absolutely vital if our farmers and rural communities are to prepare adequately for drought. By rejecting the proposal, the Howard government has deprived farmers and communities of the essential tools that they need for their businesses to survive in the long term in Australiaâs harsh climate. In a press release dated 22 December 2004, the National Farmers Federation had this to say about it:

quote.para: The future ability of Australian farmers to prepare for severe droughts and climatic events suffered a major setback yesterday when the Federal Government yesterday rejected the application to establish a Co-operative Research Centre for Climate Risk Technologies ...

speech.para: Mr Charles Burke of the National Farmers Federation had this to say:

quote.para: Farmers can be justifiably disappointed with the short-sighted decision of the CRC Selection Committee to reject the CRC for Climate Risk Technologies bid ...

speech.para: Mr Burke also said:

quote.para: ... in reviewing Australiaâs National Drought Policy over the past 18 months, NFF, industry groups and governments had agreed that future policy must focus on improved drought preparedness and on providing farmers with practical tools to better manage severe drought and climate risks.

speech.para: There we have it from the National Farmers Federation about one recent decision of the government that has not found favour with the sector and that has certainly done nothing to assist farmers to prepare long term for drought.

It is clear that the Howard government has not done enough to help Australiaâs farmers prepare for drought over the past 10 years. The government has been in power for over a decade, yet there are still yawning gaps in drought policy. That has been acknowledged by the NFF, by farmers themselves and by industry organisations. Farmer organisations, including the National Farmers Federation, have long criticised the current drought assistance arrangements as having restrictive eligibility criteria, an unnecessary and complex declaration system and discriminatory support measures resulting in more dollars finishing up in bureaucracies than in farmersâ pockets.

Labor have long agreed with the NFF that improvements are needed to the way drought relief is structured and the way it is delivered. We are pleased that in some of the measures that the government has included in this package those problems have been addressedâbut not all, and certainly the issue of the long-term drought preparedness of the sector needs more work. We have long agreed with the NFF that there need to be changes to drought policy. The Howard government first promised drought reform more than five years ago. Since then, it has announced breakthroughs in numerous press releases from the agriculture minister. There are titles such as âDrought policy reform breakthroughâ, 13 April 2005; âHeadway made on streamlining ECâ, December 2004; âProgress on drought reformâ, May 2004; âNational drought policy: the way aheadâ, April 2004; âTruss offers way forward on exceptional circumstances policyâ, 5 March 2001; and âFederal government seeks to make EC support fairer and more workableâ, on 1 May 2002. We have had a lexicon of press releases announcing the progress on drought reform, yet we have had substantial criticisms by the National Farmers Federation and we have had the comments that I have just alluded to by the Auditor-General.

talk.start.para: âYouâre not mentioning your state colleagues.

âI would certainly be happy to do that in the context of the debate if I get to that area. The parliamentary secretary, the honourable member for Parkes, is really echoing the sort of mantra that his minister has: when you fail in policy you blame the Labor states. That is an old, worn mantra from the conservative side. I challenge you to address the issues in the Auditorâs report. If you want to intervene in this debate, go to the audit report, because after 10 years it tells you exactly where the government has been on drought policy. The honourable member for Parkes was a farm leader before he came into this parliament. He knows the situation from both sides of the fence and I find it quite extraordinary that he would make the comment that he has about state government administrations when in fact he knows, as the NFF knows and as the Auditor-General knows, that this has been a substantial area of policy failure by the government.

speech.para: Let us go to the 2005 budget. At the time of this budget, the government demonstrated that it had no interest in drought reform and no real understanding of the impact of the current drought on Australian farmers. The 2005-06 budget papers show an estimated expenditure on exceptional circumstances assistance in 2004-05 of $131.9 million and a budget allocation for 2005-06 of only $59.2 millionâa cut of $72.7 million. It is not as though the government was not warned about the seriousness of the situation. Labor understands that on 15 April 2005â3Â½ weeks before the budget was handed downâthe agriculture minister was briefed by the Bureau of Meteorology at a meeting of the Primary Industries Ministerial Council and was told that the first quarter of this year was the second driest on record and that another El Nino event was likely this year. This was almost certainly not the only time in the lead-up to the budget that the government was warned about the increased likelihood that the drought would get worse, but either the government ignored the warnings or the agriculture minister failed to pass them on to his cabinet colleagues. In any case, a number of newspaper articles repeating the same warnings from the bureau appeared at about the same time. For example, a piece by Asa Wahlquist along these lines appeared in the Australian of 21 April.

One Labor commitment that has been picked up by the Howard government has been to work with the states to remove the requirement that the majority of farmers in an area seeking drought assistance prove a severe downturn in income and to replace it with a new criterion based on the impact of drought on production. Under this option, the assessment of the impact of the drought on farm incomes would be considered on an individual basis after a region was declared to be in drought. The implementation of this national production monitoring system is now being considered. At least on this one issue the minister has been able to work with state governments. Might I say, he has been able to work with them on little else. I encourage the minister to continue to pursue the development of this important Labor policy and I encourage the minister to continue working with the states and territories to develop a real national approach to drought reform.

Despite the recent rains across significant parts of Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and parts of South Australia and Queensland, around 45 per cent of Australian farmland is currently drought declared. In New South Wales, the figure is closer to 85 per cent, as I mentioned previously. Some of the most productive areas of Queensland are also in drought, as are parts of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia. In fact, large parts of New South Wales, southern Queensland and northern Victoria have been in drought since late 2002 or the early part of 2003. A significant number of families in these regions have had little or no income derived from their properties for three years in a row. The recent rains in Western Australia have considerably relieved the situation there and crop forecasts for that state are now positive, and the rains in the Eastern States have allowed some farmers to get a crop in and to at least have a chance of receiving some sort of income this year.

However, for many the outlook still remains bleak. The Bureau of Meteorology has advised that the first quarter of 2005 was the second driest on recordâonly the first quarter of 1965 was drier. In addition, it has been the hottest start to the year, with temperatures right across the continent 1.7 degrees above normal. The second hottest was 1998, when temperatures were only 1.3 degrees above normal. Each year since 2002 has been classed as a dry year, with rainfall below the historical norm. The agencies responsible for long-range climate forecasts in Australiaâthe Bureau of Meteorology, CSIRO and the Queensland climate centreâuse a variety of models to make rainfall projections for the rest of the year. The overwhelming consensus of all these models is that we are in for a hotter and drier than average year over most of the continent, especially in the east and the south-east.

That advice was available to the minister before the preparation of the budget, yet the government cut exceptional circumstances funding in that budget. In recent reviews, the forecasters have stated that they now think that there is a 50 per cent chance of average or slightly better than average rains over winter this year. However, this also means that there is a 50 per cent chance of lower than average rains over winter, and the longer term projections still indicate another dry year. Most of the models used rely to a greater or lesser extent on measurements of the southern oscillation index, a measure of the so-called El Nino effect. There is a strong consensus that the likelihood of a full-blown El Nino is still at least 50 per cent. The situation going into this El Nino event is even more precarious than it was back in 2002, when only two per cent of farmland was actually drought declared compared with 45 per cent across Australia today. Those climate projections are concerning, and the issue of long-term drought preparedness is one which the sector must now face in a very real way.

I have stated before in debate that there are many in this chamber who have experienced first hand the impact of drought on their farm enterprises, their families and their communities. My own family experience with these effects of drought is vivid to me; we went through the drought conditions that occurred in the Western District of Victoria in the late 1960s. In many ways those impacts have not changed, although for some farmers who have been able to plan both financially and resource-wise these effects have to a degree been ameliorated. But for many other farmers, persistent dry periods and lack of rain, which in some areas has run into years, have put intolerable pressure on the viability of their farm enterprises and seriously affected their long-term sustainability.

The social, economic and environmental effects of prolonged drought can be quite profound. At the drought summit I attended in Parkes, which was attended by the honourable parliamentary secretary and other members of this House, I heard first hand the social impacts the drought was having on farm families and relationships within those families and the utter desperation of many farmers who are viewing the rapid erosion of the equity base in their farms as they struggle financially with massive downturns in their farm income. Poverty and stress point to a deep social crisis in rural Australia as a result of the drought. I could go on about the economic impacts of drought on this nationâthey are substantialâbut my time in this debate is running out. I have moved my second reading amendment and I ask the honourable member for Lyons to second that amendment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. BC Scott)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment.

âI am very pleased to be speaking on the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 because it implements the measures contained in the Prime Ministerâs statement of 30 May this year outlining an additional $254 million in assistance to our farmers who are battling in the current drought conditionsâas they have been for several years. The exceptional circumstances scheme does deliver real support to our farming community. The exceptional circumstances assistance is a bit like democracyâit is not perfect but it is the best we have and it is a whole lot better with the changes announced by the Prime Minister in May this year.

speech.para: Democracy, I suppose, could have perhaps put Mark Latham in the Lodge but that does not mean we have to get rid of the concept. Imagine Mr Latham as Prime Minister during the drought. He is the man who rallied against agriculture and rural life whilst in opposition. Farmers should be thanking their lucky stars that he is not. He said things like:

quote.para: Agriculture is very good at socialising its losses and privatising its profits.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: ... if agriculture in this country is so efficient then why does it need such a high level of business welfare?

speech.para: These quotes spring to mind immediately for country people because they do not forget a party, an opposition leader and a tradition within the Labor Party of ignoring rural Australia. I was slightly surprised at some of the questioning of the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry at the announcement of the governmentâs assistance package. It seems that some journalists as well as the Labor Party have an obsession with what they termed âmarginal landâ and with the idea that farmers should effectively be taken off it if they cannot make a go of it. They were proposing that this should happen even in times of drought.

This might be trendy, popular thinking in the inner suburbs of capital cities but the reality on land in rural Australia is something markedly different. We need farmers and we certainly need young farmers for our future. For some reason farming has a bad name amongst some city dwellers and they do not realise the importance of farming to the whole community. The Deputy Prime Minister made a good point when he commented on a farmer who left his land vacant for 15 years. Over that time it inevitably became a great haven for wild animals, noxious weeds and other introduced species. This is not news and it is not a surprise to those of us who live in rural Australia.

A very similar situation has occurred in Victorian national parks where there is a process, sadly, under the current state Labor government of locking parks up and leaving them alone. This mentality not only led to the tragic events of providing additional fuel for the fires of 2003, which burnt over 900,000 hectares in my electorate in north-east Victoria, but also reminded people living in country Victoria again of the fact that we are out of sight therefore we are out of mind. We have the greatest environmental problems in rural and regional Australia, certainly in Victoriaâpest animals, wild dogs and noxious weedsâyet very little effective targeting is pursued by the state government, very little funding is providedâin reality reduced fundingâto tackle these serious problems.

God help you if you are a farmer who has land adjoining a national park in Victoria. You may as well lock the farm up and leave it because you deal single-handedly with the problems of the adjoining negligent landowner. Land does need to be managed and our farmers are innovative in doing so. The north-east of Victoria has taken a leading role in farming techniques through many schemes, particularly through our local Landcare groups.

I want to talk briefly about the Victorian governmentâs approach to drought. The measures we debate today are not at all contingent on the Victorian government doing more. Thank goodness, I hear so many farmers across Victoria shout. Only recently we had the spectacle of Premier Bracks and Mr Brumby visiting country Victoria as if drought were some sort of new phenomenon. The Victorian government thought that the drought ended in 2003. That is why they cut the drought assistance package on 7 May 2003, a very dark day for the farming community in Victoria. They went into hiding for two years and perhaps their re-emergence may have something to do with the fact that they know that the charade is up in rural and regional Victoria. Rural and regional Victorians know that the Bracks Labor government abandoned them and punished them, and very soon they will have an opportunity to pass judgment on that particular government.

We also look at New South Wales where the member for Corio decried the criticism of the state Labor government. But let us look at the facts. The New South Wales budget does provide some funding for drought assistance, but the Commonwealth government spends in two weeks what the New South Wales government has allocated for a whole year. That is a fact. It may be unpalatable but that is where it stands. This government, through its actions and financial contribution, its continual reform and innovation and its listening to people who provide financial and welfare services on the ground, is continually making changes and additions to provide support and assistance for drought preparedness and other assistance. This bill contains some of those new, innovative measures.

The member for Corio talks about reform. I hasten to suggest to the member for Corio that perhaps reform should start at home. The greatest reform that the member for Corio can engage in is reform of the Labor Party structure, particularly in Victoria where we all know and we have seen in recent reports that branch stacking is corroding the very core of the party. That is what the Australian people demand when they want an effective opposition.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I fail to see how the current contribution is relevant. I ask you to bring the member back to the bill.
(Hon. BC Scott)âThere is no point of order.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member for Corio was speaking about significant reform and an effective government. An effective government and an effective parliament require an effective opposition. If you have a corrupted process of branch stacking and the sorts of physical threats that go on in the Labor Party, this parliament is not well served.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The bill is about drought funding and I fail to see how Labor Party politics in Victoria are at all relevant to the subject matter of the bill.
âThe member for Indi may bring herself back to the bill before the House.

âI will get back to most poignant parts of the bill. I can understand why the member for Ballarat is particularly upset. It is a touchy subject and, hopefully, the forces of good and light and decent Labor Party members will prevail in the Victorian Labor Party. The main components of the more generous exceptional circumstances interest rate subsidies and a substantial increase in the off-farm assets tests are particularly welcome. There will be a more generous income test as well for exceptional circumstances payments.

speech.para: Importantly, although not the most expensive part of the package, there will be increased counselling and support services, something that I know a lot of people in my area will have benefited from and will continue to benefit from. There will also be another Enviro Fund round and a reassessment of areas not recommended by the NRAC over the last year, along with increased funding for the Country Womenâs Association to assist them in meeting the needs of local communities, a role they carry out with great dignity and awareness. Their great contribution to supporting farming families, particularly in times of drought, and providing extra support to rural communities at all times is something that may be mocked by the trendies who sit in their inner city cafes in Melbourne, but let me tell you that, as someone who lives in a rural community, I understand the very great contribution that the Country Womenâs Association makes and I applaud their national organisation and my local organisations.

On the weekend north-east Victoria and my electorate received some very good rainfalls. It is early days yet but if the views of a long-range forecaster, Wangarattaâs own John Moore, are correct we are due for some good rain in the futureâand my electorate can certainly do with it. (Quorum formed) In conclusion, I commend the bill and the reforms it contains and wholeheartedly suggest to the member for Ballarat that she joins her colleague the member for Corio in supporting not only this bill but also his preselection.

talk.start.para: âI have already seconded the amendment to the second reading of the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 which my colleague the member for Corio has moved. We believe the amendment is needed because the scope of this bill is too little, too late and, of course, not budgeted for. The drought situation in Australia is really bad and likely to get worse. The relief payment is very necessary and probably well overdue for many families. It seems, though, that this government ignored it in the budget and had to be dragged kicking and screaming to allocate funds to suffering farmers.

speech.para: Why wasnât it considered in the budget? Most people know that around 45 per cent of Australiaâs farmland is currently drought declared and in New South Wales the figure is closer to 80 or 85 per cent. Other regions also have significant drought areas including Victoria, South Australia and WA. Although Tasmania has not got to a drought stage yet, northern and eastern Tasmania are very dry. Some of these areas have been dry since 2002. The Met bureau has advised that the first quarter of 2005 was the second driest on record. Additionally, it was hotter than ever recorded, with temperatures around the continent 1.7 degrees above normal. But we knew this and we can predict through a number of different sorts of modelling that we are going to go on being dry for a lot longer yet. So although the government has provided some bandaid reliefâand I know it is much neededâwhat is going to happen in the future?

As with the water policy, drought was being discussed by this government five or six years agoâand since then there have been lots of conferences, roundtables, papers and discussions, but nothing seems to be happening to develop a proper strategy to deliver a more permanent answer. We have to look at this in a strategic way, taking into account the signals of climate change as they are now. We have to plan a little for the future and understand that perhaps we need to look at farming practices, at how we can start the drought-proofing process and at how to encourage farmers to consider their farm plans in light of changing circumstances.

One who has been following this debate as well as working on water issues is Professor Peter Cullen. His article in the Australian on Monday, 30 May is worth considering. He understands the farmersâ ethos; he knows what a desperate time it is when farmers have to watch sheep weaken and die, when they can no longer afford to buy fertiliser or food or when they battle to meet interest payments on borrowed money from banks, as most farmers have to. In the article, Peter said:

quote.para: It is likely that our climate is changing and that many of our agricultural areas are likely to become hotter and drier.
Blanket solutions are not likely to be effective, andâ

speech.para: he suggestedâ

quote.para: governments and communities need to start working together to develop solutions for each region.

speech.para: The other point he made that we really do have to address is:

quote.para: Some of the marginal low-rainfall areas into which we have pushed farming in the good years will never be viable and we should stop pretending that handouts each year will solve this problem.

speech.para: History has told us this. It goes back a long wayâGeorge W. Goyder was the first one to challenge the wisdom of going into marginal lands. He was a well-respected surveyor of South Australia from 1861 to 1893 who spent most of his life wandering around South Australia and the Northern Territory and experienced the shattering disappointment of drought. Goyderâs line of rainfall indicated the limit of the rainfall which coincided with the southern boundary of saltbush country. It separated lands suitable for agriculture from those fit for pastoral use only. It also marked areas of reliable and unreliable annual rainfall. When agricultural land became scarce, combined with good seasons and crops during the early 1870s, the expected income of land sales persuaded the government to disregard the line and allow farmers to buy land north of it. Farming outside Goyderâs line is still very risky, but also inviting, especially after good rains. The main problems of the past were not the land or climate but smallholdings and poor farming techniques. Cullen went on to say:

quote.para: In each region we should critically examine the wealth that has been created by agriculture each year during the last 20 years, and compare it with the costs, the direct costs of government subsidies, and the indirect costs of land degradation being worn by all of us. In some areas, I suspect it just will not add up.

speech.para: Cullen pointed to Goyder as an example:

quote.para: Despite the warnings of 19th century surveyor George Goyder, who said it could not be sustained farming pushed beyond these sustainable limits.

speech.para: Then there were three or four good years when farmers opened up new lands and governments continued their developments, spreading out into the hinterland of the towns. So what happened when the normal weather patterns returned? As was noted, everyone went broke and they walked away from the land. If we leave it to the market to sort out those farms that are viable and those that are not, there will be a lot of hurt. It is a brutal process.

So what should be done? Peter Cullen thinks that the most unsustainable areas will revert to larger pastoral properties and therefore will not support the number of people trying to make a living from the landscape. But since these areas have been cleared, and fertilisers, weeds and feral animals have been introduced, the land still has to be managed. Governments and farmers cannot just walk away. There should be some method of helping farmers off the most marginal land and putting in place a stewardship program so that land already degraded has a chance of recovery. There needs to be some financial assistance to allow this to happen without breaking the farmers.

We need new ideas and we need government to support innovation. This is where this government and this minister have failed abysmally. They have done nothing about activating recommendations from two recent parliamentary water inquiries. In fact, they have not even bothered to give a response. That is a shameful way to treat the work of a committee and all the people who made submissions to it.

Recently, the Deputy Prime Minister was seen supporting Peter Andrews on Australian Story. You might remember that Peter Andrews was a racehorse breeder and farmer credited with remarkable success in converting degraded, salt-ravaged properties into fertile, drought-resistant pastures. His methods are at odds with conventional scientific wisdom, but now many are sitting up and taking notice of his methods, and the process is proving to be a winner. But the poor fellow went broke because, although the Minister for Transport and Regional Services thought his farming process had a lot of a merit, the minister did not pitch in to get some research funds to keep this man goingâand maybe prevent many farmers in New South Wales and Victoria from being quite so affected by drought. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services has failed againânot a good record! No wonder the he is looking to get out of parliament soon. The ABCâs Australian Story brought up many important issues and possible solutions that go far beyond anything the ministerâs department has offered.

By all means, get on with helping families with the exceptional circumstances payment, but for goodness sake, get on with searching for some solutions. Australia is running out of time for messing about with bandaid measures. We must do research and we need to talk to people like Peter Andrews to see whether he is right. Let us get some departmental people out in the field to help him promote his method and test the areas. And pay the poor manâhe cannot go on living on fresh air. It is just not fair of the government to say they support him and then ignore his plight.

Some areas are more able to cope by using this process than others, so we need many other solutions, including letting some of the land revert to natural growth with supported, careful husbandry. So I support the amendments to this bill as they address many of the points I have been making about the failures by this government, which is living on a reputation of splurging money on simplistic things and ignoring the real needs of our communities.

talk.start.para: âI was not going to enter into this second reading debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 during the short time available but the member for Lyons has spoken a lot about Professor Peter Cullenâs contribution to the debate on this matter. I do not understand how we can take seriously Professor Cullen, who asserted that it takes 22,000 litres of water to grow a kilogram of rice, when he was wrong and has done serious damage to this great industry. In fact, it takes between 1,500 and 1,900 litres to grow a kilogram of rice. If Professor Cullenâs views were correct it would take more than the water that is available in the Murray-Darling Basin just to grow the rice in my electorate. So I do not see that he has an enormous amount of credibility in many of these debates. (Quorum formed)

speech.para: I will now move to the more important issues and matters around this incredibly important bill. Todayâs farmer is increasingly, and somewhat unfairly, expected to be a large-scale landscape gardener, a park ranger and a manager of urban water catchments, all for free. These are the words of the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestryâand he is right. A recent report commissioned by the Australian Farm Institute found that agricultureâs contribution to our countryâs economy is almost four times as much as is it generally credited with. The agriculture and food sector remains an important driver of Australiaâs economic activity. Primary production especially is the lifeblood of a healthy rural Australia. The national land and water resources audit has revealed that productivity growth has not come at the expense of the national resource base, with the fertility of our land actually increasing. It has been indicated that some of our farmers have move into marginal areas and simply cannot survive there, but many areas have been thriving and prosperous under farming activity.

The initiative and drive of the nationâs farmers has underwritten the sectorâs profitable expansion and continues to reshape the mix of farm goods that we produce, highlighting rural Australiaâs flexibility, resilience and diversity. But, as the minister for agriculture has always recognised, our industries face many traditional challenges. Declining terms of trade; highly competitive and interconnected global markets; changing consumer preferences; protectionist international trading policies; and a natural resource base that imposes land, water and climatic limits on expansion are just a few of the familiar issues. But we must move past the familiar issues to the issue that many are not able to cope withâthat is, this extraordinary drought. I would like to quote a farmer in my electorate. He said:

quote.para: 1. We are not just farmers. We are family owned businesses. Some of us have survived and prospered for 100 years or more. But after all these years my generation is looking like the one that will fail due to this critical prolonged drought.

2. Family farms are the most efficient. Farmers in Australia are very proud people and in most cases the best managers of our most precious resource our land. Big corporate owned farms cannot farm like us.

3. We have provided for normal drought by storing feed and developing water storage on farms with dams, tanks and pipelines. All at a huge cost, but it goes to make us self-sufficient. We have put aside money where possible to sustain us in normal times of drought. I have worked through two droughts and survived but this one is going to break me.
4. This drought is like no other in historyâ

speech.para: What we are dealing with is like nothing else in historyâ

quote.para: It has gone on for so long it has wiped out all we have done to prepare. Little feed left, little water left, sold off stock and no money in most cases we are at the limit of our borrowing.

speech.para: That is why, when I and the member for Parkes welcomed the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister to our electorates to look at the farms ravaged by droughtâwhich no amount of management and good planning can compensate forâit was refreshing to see a real-time response which will enable farmers to be as resilient through this year of drought as they have been in the past 100 years. The Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister met with two very good groups in my electorate. They met a group led by Coral Russell; they met Bill Thompson and Tony Paton from the rural counselling service; and they met my other rural counsellor, Peter Gerarde-Smithâall of whom know exactly what it is like to be devastated in this area. To see the response to that meeting was typically gratifying for me. Hopefully, many of my farmers will now be able to go forward and not feelâafter three, four, five or six generations in farmingâthat they are the failures and the ones who will have to walk off properties that are not in marginal areas.

We have problems associated with graphs and statistics which, in my electorate, have shown that 2003 was perhaps a better year than 2001-02 or 2004-05. Those graphs are very deceiving, because two large falls in February and December 2003 contributed 46.5 per cent of our total rain received. However, these falls were outside the growing season for the 2003 cereal crop so, whilst there may have been a small amount of relief in some pasture growth, there was no real benefit from those rains. In fact, that rainfall served to do only one thing: distort annual rainfall activity and graphs. It had no bearing on our cropping or productivity, and therefore no bearing on the economy of the farmers and the communities that rely on them.
