As the member for Riverina, I am very thankful for the drought assistance package that is before this House. I am very grateful to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Warren Truss, the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, and the Prime Minister, John Howard, for at least taking the time to come out to my electorate to listen to people and to look at and discuss the very real issues that these farmers are confronting through absolutely no fault of their own. Nobody has been able to manage for this drought. The government has tried to respond in a very real wayâand it will respond. It certainly will improve the lives of many of my farmers and many of my community members. It is true that our rural economy is declining simply because of the problems associated with this drought but Minister Truss has responded with over and above what was expected.

My farmers were so busy trying to survive with no staff or assistance on their properties, given their very significant plight, that many of them forgot to or did not think to put in for their exceptional circumstances interest rate subsidy by the closing date for applications. The minister responded after my representations so, for those areas where the EC declarations cease prior to 30 May 2005 or expired 28 days prior to the notification to state and territory ministers of revised guidelines, those applicants were able to get a 28-day grace period for them to put in their application. I thanked the minister for this, something that has been well and truly appreciated at this very difficult time. When I put out the press release that welcomed the additional drought support for the farmers, producers and rural communities that I represent, I was overwhelmed. I am very thankful for any help that I can give to the people that I represent because, purely and simply, they deserve it. Nobody deserves help more than the people that I represent and nobody should have to gain their stripes in something as so unrelenting as this drought. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, on indulgence: In question time today I asked the Prime Minister a question about penalty rates and suggested that the maximum that could be lost as a result of a loss of a penalty rate in the case I referred to was $260 a week. I should have said â$240 a weekâ. Whilst that error was not pertinent to the thrust of the question, I nonetheless correct it.

debateinfo.title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT AMENDMENT (EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES RELIEF PAYMENT) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âThe Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 amends the Farm Household Support Act 1992 to give effect to some of the measures in the 2005 drought assistance package announced on 30 May 2005. You would think by the way the government are talking that the drought has caught them by surpriseâthat suddenly, a scant few weeks after a budget that promised over $22 billion worth of spending, it has suddenly dawned on them that the drought is still actually going on. The governmentâs handling of the worst drought on record has smacked of absolute incompetence. The government have failed to take heed of the warnings of their own experts and to plan for the prolonged nature of the drought. They cut funding in the budget for the exceptional circumstances program and then, some three weeks later, had to put a new relief package in place. The government have failed to manage the exceptional circumstances application process in a timely and transparent way, and farmers continue to be hampered by red tape as they try to access the program. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Meteorologyâs National Climate Centre and the Queensland Centre for Climate Applications have all been warning that the last five years have been amongst the driest on record and that there is no evidence that the situation is likely to improve in the long term. Drought is not new to this country: it is a problem farmers have had to contend with since the late 1880s. Australia has experienced several severe and prolonged droughts. They include the Federation Drought of 1895-1902; the 1914-15 drought, the World War II droughts between 1937 and 1945, the 1982-83 drought, and the El Nino associated droughts from 1991 to 1995 and again in 1997. However, the present drought has been particularly severe and it has stretched farmersâ resilience, resources and resolve.

speech.para: The lack of action, vision and leadership is becoming a theme common to this government. While I support this bill, I note there is so much the Howard government could have done over the last five years to reduce the hardship that farmers in drought-affected areas have been experiencing. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has given a whole new meaning to the saying âall talk and no actionâ. The government first promised drought relief reform more than five years ago and since then has announced breakthroughs in numerous press releases from the agriculture minister with titles that have included âDrought policy reform breakthroughâ, 13 April 2005; âHeadway made on streamlining ECâ; âTruss welcomes EC drought reform supportâ; âProgress on drought reformâ, 19 May 2004; âNational drought policy: the way aheadâ; âFederal government seeks to make EC support fairer and more workableâ; and âTruss offers way forward on exceptional circumstances policyâ. If the minister had put less effort into writing media releases and more effort into backing his public comments with policy commitments, rural businesses, families and workers would not be feeling the increased anxiety and depression that they are currently feeling.

The frustration over the Howard governmentâs talk fest on drought assistance has drawn criticism from the National Farmers Federation president, Mr Cornish, who said in an article in the Canberra Times on 27 May this year:

quote.para: Let us hope that after five years of discussions the Prime Minister, following his drought tour last week, shows the national leadership required and takes full control of the EC system, paving the way for the long overdue reforms required to establish a fair and equitable EC system in this country ...

speech.para: However, the list of the governmentâs critics does not stop at the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Labor Party. The Australian National Audit Office report on drought assistance released earlier this month shines a light on the lack of planning, strategy and coordination in this policy area. Some of the reportâs key findings include:

quote.para: The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry ... did not have a specific preparedness or contingency plan for drought ...
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
Planning byâ

speech.para: the departmentâ

quote.para: did identify some risks to delivery of EC ... however there were no specific treatment strategies identified corresponding to these risks.

para.inline: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

quote.para: ... nor did risk plans identify the possibility that substantial additional measures might be needed if the drought worsened.

para.inline: Â Â Â Â Â Â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

quote.para: There was no whole-of-government implementation plan ...
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
... there was no integrated communication strategy.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
As well, there was no whole-of-government implementation framework to support the ... full range of drought assistance measures.

speech.para: No wonder the Howard governmentâs drought policy is in such a mess. It beggars belief that, with much of the country gripped by prolonged drought over the last decade, the minister did not even have a plan for what to do if the drought got worse. Nothing encapsulates the neglect of planning in this area more than the $72.7 million cut to the estimated expenditure on exceptional circumstances assistance in the 2005-06 budget. It is beyond belief when 45 per cent of Australiaâs farmland is currently drought declared; with states like New South Wales the figure is closer to 85 per cent. But, not wanting to stop there, the Howard government knew an El Nino event was likely. Instead of increasing EC assistance in the budget, what did it do? It actually cut estimated expenditure.

On 15 April 2005âthree and a half weeks before the budget was handed downâthe agriculture minister was briefed by the Bureau of Meteorology at a meeting of the Primary Industries Ministerial Council and told that the first quarter of this year was the second driest on record and that another El Nino event was likely this year. Either the government ignored the warning, the agriculture minister failed to pass it on or they decided that they did not want to talk about the drought in the budget papers because of the impact that would have on the economyâs bottom line. In any case, a number of newspaper articles outlining these warnings appeared at the same time, so it is not as though it was not known in the lead-up to the budget that there was going to be a problem with drought assistance. The drought that started in 2002-03 has been particularly severe by historical standards. The consequences have included a decline in crop production of more than 50 per cent in 2002-03. Flow-on effects have contributed to a downturn for rural businesses and fewer regional employment opportunities.

I want to address the arbitrary nature of how the boundaries of EC are declared and how the assessment process is conducted. The Australian National Audit Office report directed particular attention to the assessment of EC applications. It found:

quote.para: ... lack of a clear standard for information required in an EC application. Stakeholders, such as peak industry bodies and farmer organisations, also commented that the amount of information required for an application was extensive. In some instances, the information was difficult to obtain ...

speech.para: Because of the way EC areas are declared many farmers are suffering arbitrarily. In my electorate, Gordon and Ballan are both considered to be EC drought declared areas, but if you travel just 50 kilometres west to Snake Valley, Beaufort and Learmonth the farmers are not so lucky. They have been unable to get their areas EC declared, despite receiving exactly the same levels of rainfall and having the same pressures as the farmers in Gordon and Ballan. Despite being in the same boat by virtue of being on the wrong side of a line, farmers of equal need will receive varying levels of support. The real concern for farmers is not so much the insufficient financial assistance from EC funding but the eligibility criteria. I know that farmers who are on the other side of that line are still doing it toughâthey still sit around the kitchen table at night wondering how they are going to pay the bills and buy stock for the next season.

In my area the process has been particularly painful. Time after time we have had applications going in and the applicants being told more information was needed. In fact, you actually have to pay to access the informationâand where do you have to go to pay for access to that information? You have to go to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, a federal government office, so you can submit an application to the federal government. It just seems absolutely ridiculous to me that we are in those circumstances. On each occasion the application for EC assistance for those areas has been rejected. As I said, what that has resulted in is a small proportion of my electorate being drought declared while other parts that are suffering just as badly remain undeclared. Because they have not been able to obtain information or there has been a lack of clarity about the information required, those farmers and businesses in those communities have had to go without.

The arbitrary nature of exceptional circumstances funding was also picked up in the Audit Office report. It noted that there is no standard approach to describing EC areas in the EC applications which were subsequently announced in press releases. As a result, the descriptions of exceptional circumstances declared industries and regions were at times complicated. As well, some maps of the EC declared areas did not accord clearly with descriptions of the areas.

After five years of talk from this government any increase in assistance to farmers is absolutely welcome. However, if the government thinks that it has done nearly enough, it is gravely mistaken. There is still much to be done and improved on. The government has failed to take on board in a timely way the warnings of the CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Queensland Centre for Climate Applications. It has failed to fund the proposed CRC for climate risk technologies, which might have actually helped to address some of these issues in the future. Its decision to scrap the drought investment allowance is a great disappointment to many farmers. Its failure to adequately fund drought relief in this yearâs budget, despite the fact that it had information about it, shows that the government is not serious about drought policy at all. It only moves to deal with the issues when they appear in the media. That is no way to run your public policy program.

I say to the member for Indiâwho in this debate could not even manage to speak for the 10 minutes allocated to her without attempting to take some cheap political shots and who had not even seen a regional or rural area until she tottered down the highway in her Manolo Blahaniks to try and win a seat off the National Partyâthat it takes more to represent a regional or rural area and do something about drought funding than just sticking your name down on a bill that happens to have something about farmers in it.

It is important that the government implements an effective and long-term plan for addressing the problems farmers experience during sustained drought, because the livelihood and prosperity of farms not only impacts on farmers and their families but has a direct link to the vibrancy of regional and rural communities. It has been estimated by the National Farmers Federation that up to 70,000 jobs have been lost because of the current drought. Recent studies by Charles Sturt University of drought-hit towns in New South Wales show jobs losses from drought include teaching, retail, hospitality, apprenticeships and skilled labour, as well as seasonal farm labouring jobs. The farming community in my electorate is in many respects the lifeblood of towns like Ballarat, Ballan and Learmonth. If we do not address the long-term issues that are facing farmers in rural communities, we put at peril the economic as well as the cultural wellbeing of regional Australia.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak to the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005. Many have spoken about the drought. There have been a number of matters of public importance and other debates and there has been much in the press. Like many members in this House I also am pleased to say that large sections of my electorate have received relatively good rain in the last week. But I, and I am sure other members from country areas, would hate urban dwellers to assume that the drought was effectively broken by that rain. Obviously it was not. There are many areasâI think some are within the electorate of the member for Riverinaâthat have not received substantial rain at all. So it has been a patchy start to the winter season.

speech.para: I would like to raise a number of issues, some directly related to the bill and some indirectly. Firstly, I believe that the National Rural Advisory Council will be travelling to parts of New South Wales over this week to look at areas that were included in the exceptional circumstances arrangements but have been out of that arrangement for some time, varying in months of course. I would encourage the council to have a very close look at those areas they will be considering within the New England electorate. In doing so I encourage them to look closelyâand I think the minister hinted at this the other day, and others have talked about itâat the micro areas that may be impacted far more than the broader areas that the drought policy criteria tends to look at.

That is one of the concerns that many people have, and it is related to the weather stations and to rainfall over a particular period of time. As we know, not everybody gets the same amount of rain within a particular region. There can be other impacting forces on the determination of criteria, and a farmer, even though he may be in the same region as another farmer, could have different criteria related to his drought circumstances. One of the things we have to look at very closely in the future is the way in which we measure rainfall. If rainfall is to be a part determinant of drought policy we have to come up with better ways of recognising the micro differences that occur within a region, rather than trying to blanket a total region as being in drought or out of drought. Obviously there are areas of grey that do need recognition. I think the minister is well aware of that. I hope that in discussions with the states, the NFF and others they will come up with better criteria for the future.

There have been a number of publications, articles and opinion pieces on the drought over the last year or so, particularly in relation to drought policy. I was singled out for some degree of criticism, I think by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, about some of my comments on the announcement by the Prime Minister of another $250 million in expenditure for drought funding. Most people welcomed that funding. I welcomed it, but I did have some critical comments on the way in which the drought funding has been sold. I would like to go back through some of those issues again.

This has been the worst drought in 100 years. One of the things that happens to farmers during a drought is that they run out of cash. Most of them have some sort of debt arrangement to meetâfor instance, they will have interest rates plus the capital to meet. One of the comments I have made from time to time is that the ambition of drought policy, if there is a one in 100-years drought, should be to attempt to freeze the financial position of those farmers involved so that, when this natural disaster ends, the agricultural sector is in a financial position to move forward productively. I do not think the existing drought criteria do that at all. In fact in many senses they do the reverse.

When you analyse the figures, you find that the interest rate subsidy component of exceptional circumstances expenditure over the last three years was $237 million. There has been a lot of talk, over the last two years at least, that the government has expended a billion dollars on drought. That is not the case; in fact the minister has admitted that. What the government has done is assist the financial predicament in relation to the interest rate component of the farm sector with $237 million. That is $79 million a year in the worst drought in recorded history for one of the major industries in Australia. But we hear the cry that this is a major subsidy to agriculture, that this is a major subsidy to the farming sector. We hear some of the economic pundits saying that it should not be occurring and that it is a misuse of public moneys et cetera.

I take you back, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, to a period of time in which you would have been very involved, when there was a major change in public policy in this place. The government was looking at introducing the goods and services tax. That was a significant change. It was not a climatically driven change but it was a significant change in public policy, and in fact it was one with which I agreed. I was not a member of this parliament at that time. Part of the political reaction to the goods and services tax was from the building industry, which is another very important industry to Australia. The building industry said, âThe introduction of this new tax will mean that the price of a house, all building construction, will go up by 10 per cent.â

Coming into the 2001 election, the government listened to what those people were saying and put in place an assistance package for the building industry called the First Home Owners Scheme. That provided $14,000 for people attempting to buy or build their first home and was an indirect incentive to the building industry. I am pleased Minister Truss has entered the chamber. The $79 million per year provided over the last three years for what we all agree is the worst drought in living history has been matched by the assistance to the building industry for a year longerâover four yearsâof $5.2 billion by way of the First Home Owners Scheme. I am not whingeing about that, and I do not hear anybody in here whingeing about it either. They see it as a means of not only assisting young people into homes but also assisting the industry to survive the movement towards a goods and service tax arrangement.

I noticed Alan Mitchell in the Australian Financial Review on 1 June making a range of comments on the viability of farmers and the dreadful drought package that had been given to them. I remind Alan Mitchell and other commentators that, effectively, $237 million has been spent in three years on government assistance to farmers. Most of the other moneyâand the minister will agree with me: he will get up and say it is $680 million; it is now probably over $720 millionâhas been for household support, which this bill is about. Anybody who is unemployed in Australia is entitled to household support. For the economic commentators and, on some occasions, the minister and the government to construe that as singling out farmers for assistance and including it as assistance is, I think, misrepresenting the facts. The real assistance that has gone to agriculture over the last three years is around $237 million.
Alan Mitchell, the economics editor of the Financial Review, makes another comment:

quote.para: The interest rate subsidy is an abomination. It subsidises most generously the farmers who are most heavily in debt.

speech.para: It does not do that at allâand I hope the minister supports me here because I am supporting him. In fact, the criteria that are established mean that those who are very heavily in debt are non-viable. The minister made mention of this on the day of the announcement of the extra $250 million. Those people are not considered viable. And if you are not viable you are not entitled to exceptional circumstances assistance. If people need proof of that, I refer themâlisteners and membersâto a very interesting article written by Michael Duffy, published in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, 18 June, headed: âFarmers are pushed beyond limitâ.

Michael Duffy quite rightly makes an attack on the New South Wales Carr government for the way in which they have pushed farmers to the wall through environmental policy without compensation. His arguments are very valid. Using Peter Spencerâs situation as an example, Michael Duffy describes how changes in environmental policy have forced Peter Spencerâs property into becoming a non-viable arrangement. When he needed help because of the drought, the Commonwealth government could not or would not assist him because his farm was considered non-viable. So I suggest that Alan Mitchell refer to Michael Duffyâs article and get his facts right before he starts suggesting that the farmers who are the most indebted are the most assisted. The criteria do not work that way.

In conclusion, I want to make a couple of points. As I have said, I am pleased the minister is here. I and others have suggested that, rather than the piecemeal arrangement that we have now with the states and the Commonwealth arguing from time to time about who is right and who is wrong, we should in the future move towards establishing a national natural disaster fund. To show how easy it is to raise large amounts of money and have such a fund in place so that you can remove from the political process access to a disaster fund, it takes only one dollar per week from every Australian to raise a billon dollars in a year. That is oversimplifying itâI am well aware of thatâbut it shows how very few dollars from many people can raise a lot of money.

When you analyse the disasters that have occurred in Australia since 1974, there has been only one natural disaster that has cost over $1 billion in a yearâthat is, the Newcastle earthquake. Natural disasters in Australia are costing the nation about $200 million per annum. Twenty cents a week from every Australian would cover, on average, the disasters that occur within Australia. Wouldnât that be a better way of addressing not only natural disasters such as this one, which is a drought, but also the Wollongong mudslide where the people who were impacted by that mudslide lived in great uncertainty? Arguments went on between the insurance companies, the government and others about who was wrong, who was right and who should pay. A fund should be there for all disasters: cyclones, earthquakes, mudslides, major hail stormsâif they are deemed to be a natural disasterâand a whole range of other events in between.

The point I am making is that this parliament should take the lead and establish a national natural disaster fund and the criteria that determine a natural disasterâand that should not be every dry spell. I am a farmer; we should not be compensated for every dry spell we have. But when we enter a zone such as the one we are in now there should be criteria that are recognised in a special way to preserve the integrity of agriculture so that when the event is over the industry can come out the other end and be productive for the nation.

There are a couple of other points I would like to make. One is in support of the member for Mallee, who has from time to time raised the issue of climate. Drought is about climate. This nation does not do enough work by way of research on the ways and means of improving the climate. I suggest that issues such as drought seeding, which the member for Mallee has looked at very closely and argued for strongly in this place, be reconsidered in any long-term drought assistance package. I note that the New South Wales government is doing some work of this kind in the Kosciusko area at this very moment and, I am told, has had good results so far. A lot of similar work has been done in Tasmania in past years.

In my view, assistance to find ways of managing the microclimate of agriculture has not been pushed hard enough. I am not saying there has not been any assistance; there has been. I have been involved in no-till agricultureâthe minister would know all about thatâwhich some people call zero till and others call conservation tillage. It is a practice where you reduce the cultivation, the active disturbance of the soil which drives soil out, and replace it essentially with chemical farming and that maintains the residues on top of your soil. Both the humus and the infiltration rates are increased so that you get more water into the soil rather than the water running off causing erosion and all those sorts of micro issues. I would possibly be one of the longest serving farmers using that initiative. We have land that has not been cultivated but that has been cropped continuously since 1977. This land has been continuously analysed for the micro flora and fauna, soil structure, soil texture, infiltration rates and those sorts of things. The flora and fauna have essentially been in good soil, I must admit, but there are a lot of good soils particularly in New South Wales and southern Queensland. That in itself is drought control because you are storing moisture in the subsoil for when the crop needs it. I would urge the minister and the parliament to look at it. There are similar measures that can be used to try to encourage farmers to adopt measures that do more for the microclimate in which they are actually farming.

The problems that farmers are facing now are seen by many as drought related, but in a lot of cases it is lack of profitability and the farmersâ incapacity to fund their way through a very difficult time. Australia has to look at what it can do in its domestic agricultural sector to assist those people become more profitable. I know that I am starting to sound like a cracked record in this place, but I cannot understand why, given the price of oilâthe Treasurer was on his feet today talking about the price of oilâand given the circumstances of greenhouse gases with the Kyoto arrangements where we as a nation and as a globe have to move to more renewable energies, we are not encouraging our farm sector to move into some of these renewable energy areas such as ethanol. I have a bill before the house at the moment to mandate 10 per cent ethanol use. That in one fell swoop could save the sugar industry and could utilise many millions of tonnes of grain that we currently export to corrupt markets, only to go and buy oil with the money from another corrupt market. Our governments should be looking at real policy such as that to increase the price of the products they sell so that, once a dry spell or a drought comes along, the farm sector is in a more profitable position to face that adversity. I do not see any of those sorts of things that I, and others, have mentioned in drought policy as it is at the moment.

All I seeâand I was involved with farm organisations before coming into the New South Wales parliamentâis a continuation of the same old argument by misguided commentators in an economic sense who are trying to create the old country-urban division over subsidy to agriculture. Australia has to make some decisions: do we need agriculture in this land; do we need an inland Australia? This Australian parliament has to start putting in place policy that actually drives that, rather than the reverse that has occurred through some aspects of competition policy and economic rationalist thought.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: âAt the outset I thank all those members who have contributed to this debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005, most of whom having made some comments about drought and its impact on Australia. While the honourable member for New England is still in the chamber, I will respond to a couple of the issues that he raised. I share his concern about some of the comments on drought policy made in the capital city media over recent times and I have said that publicly. One of my pet hates is when university academics living on a 100 per cent government funded salary criticise assistance to farmers in their times of need. They are living in ivory towers when they expect massive funding for their university or for their academic institution but then criticise any government funding that might be provided to other groups. IÂ think there does need to be a balance in this debate, and some of the newspaper commentary has left a lot to be desired.

speech.para: I guess I can understand the frustration that city people feel about this drought having gone on and on, but their frustration pales into insignificance compared with the pain suffered by those who have to live with the drought and seek to manage it. In those circumstances there is a need for some degree of sympathy and understanding and an acknowledgment that, when the good times return seasonally on the land, farmers will once again contribute mightily to the national economy and ensure that the kinds of services and facilities that people in the city enjoy can be funded from a national perspective. I accept that there is a need for us to look constructively and in the long term at the way in which we manage our rural lands and how effectively we are able to work towards ensuring that people are able to endure droughts as painlessly as possible.

It needs to be said that the reforms that have occurred in agriculture other the years have made an enormous difference to the way in which we have been able to see our way through this drought. The honourable member for New England referred to no-till farming, which has meant that crops have been harvested in some places where in a previous generation, in a previous drought, that could never have happened. The way in which we manage our irrigation water now and the supplies of our impoundment are so much more professional that we are able to see through circumstances which in the past could never have been possible. I wonder what catastrophe there would have been had this particular drought occurred in 1900, when most of these capacities to adjust were not in place.

I have no doubt that the governmentâs Farm Management Deposits Scheme, the FarmBis training program and a range of other initiatives that we have taken under the AAA package have also helped farmers to prepare for the drought and enabled them to see through some circumstances in a way that otherwise may not have been possible.

The member for New England said a couple of things that it may not surprise him to hear I do not agree with. On a number of occasions he has sought to discount the amount of Commonwealth contribution that has been going to drought affected farmersâI think unfairly. The reality is that the payments that have been made to farmers in direct cash payments amount to about $680 million. There is about another $80 million that has been provided by way of concessions in access to the Youth Allowance and also the cost of providing health care cards to affected farmers. I do not think it is fair to say that a big proportion of this $680 million would be available to farmers just because all people are entitled to unemployment benefits when they are unemployed. The reality is that most farmers would not qualify for Newstart allowance because they cannot meet one of the fundamental tests: they cannot abandon their property and go and search for full-time work. So concessions are put in place to enable farmers to access these welfare payments, which I acknowledge are paid at the same rate as payments to recipients of Newstart allowance. This bill will make the tests associated with access to these relief payments even more generous and therefore again underpins the fact that this is a genuine contribution and can reasonably be counted as a part of the exceptional circumstances assistance available to farmers.

I note the opposition is prepared to support the bill but has put forward an amendment containing a series of criticisms. For me, the sadness in looking at the opposition amendment is the clear indication that the amendment gives about the Labor Partyâs lack of understanding about drought and drought policy issues. Almost every single one of the Labor Partyâs proposals is flawed and inaccurate; they are simply factually wrong. In those circumstances, it is disappointing that the alternative government has so little understanding of the issues associated with drought. It is simply not true to say, for instance, that there was inadequate funding for drought relief in this yearâs budget. The funding provided was in keeping with what was expected would be required to meet the needs of farmers in the already declared areas. When new areas are declared, as has been happening ever since the drought began, new estimates are provided through the additional estimates process. In addition to that, extra money will now be required and provided because of the new measures announced by the Prime Minister on 30 May. It is essentially an entitlements based system, and whatever money is required to meet those entitlements will be provided.

I am surprised at the suggestion that, to use the oppositionâs words, there is âfailure to provide long term financial certainty for the Rural Financial Counselling Serviceâ. There is four-year funding in the budget. The funding is secure. It is true that the government has undertaken a reviewâand we have obtained cooperation from the states in thisâof how we can deliver the Rural Financial Counselling Service more effectively in the future, but the funding is clearly in place. There is no suggestion of cutting funding. Indeed, the announcement of 30 May referred to increased funding and the provision of 10 additional counsellors.

There is a suggestion that we have failed to take notice of warnings that there might be a drought. I would be interested in challenging the opposition to produce those warnings. I am sure I could find quotations from each of the instrumentalities that have been mentioned saying that they expected seasonal conditions to be average or above average. One of the things that I have well and truly learned as a farmer over the years is to treat all of these forecasts with a fair degree of scepticism. When you have SOI figures moving from the lowest level ever recorded to a plus figure in one month, it makes you really wonder how reliable these scientific assessments areâor, for that matter, the El Nino effect. I think we understand the implications less now than when the words were first invented.

I do not think it is reasonable to ask a farmer to plan their drought preparedness measures on the basis of what might happen to be predicted by the centre for climate research, a climate warning centre, a Queensland climate centre, the CSIRO or, for that matter, anybody else. You have to make your decisions on the basis of the best available information, but those who do not plant their crop can be absolutely certain that they are not going to harvest any. Farmers will take the riskâand it is a risk based on sound judgmentâto plant their crop if they believe there is a reasonable prospect of achieving success.

Even in a drought, even in a year that is predicted to be a drought, we sometimes have areas that fortuitously miss out on the drought, that get rainfall coming through; people are therefore able to succeed in a year like that. It even happened this year. After we have had a couple of good falls of rain in some places, who would be brave enough to stand in this House and say that we are not going to get a wheat crop this year? It is still quite possible. Yet a fortnight ago most people were prepared to discard that possibility almost altogether.

It is true that we have been struggling to reform the drought assistance arrangements for some time, but the oppositionâs amendment suggests that somehow or other it is the Commonwealthâs fault that it has not been possible to achieve reforms. The amendment refers to proposals in May 2002 to introduce a range of reforms. It is true: the states were happy to agree to a range of reforms so long as the Commonwealth paid 100 per cent of the cost. Whenever it comes to any kind of reforms that the states should bear a share ofâeven a traditional shareâthey run miles away. It is simply nonsense to suggest that there was any agreement in May 2002. We certainly agreed on some desirable changes that could be made to the system, but none of the statesâwith the possible exception of Western Australiaâhas ever been prepared to make any compromises at all towards a proper and fair sharing arrangement for the cost of exceptional circumstances arrangements.

There are a number of quite significant issues that have been raised by members. I just refer to one other, and that is the reference by a couple of members of the opposition to the ANAO report into drought assistance. Once again, they seriously misrepresented the tone and the content of that report. The report made it very clear that Australiaâs drought assistance measures have been responsive and effective. It made it clear that the agencies concerned had worked very hard to ensure that assistance reached farmers and their families in a timely and user-friendly manner. The overall conclusion of the ANAO report was that the agencies had made considerable efforts to deliver drought assistance measures to affected communities and that the delivery of that assistance, on the whole, was accurate and timely. The ANAO did make seven recommendations, all of which were readily accepted by my department, but they would all fall into the category of finetuning the way in which the EC assistance could be provided more effectively.

There was some comment about the time taken to deal with applications. We have had an unprecedented number of applicationsâmore than in the entire history of our nation: 84. Of those, 66 per cent were assessed in eight weeks or less. The ANAO report confirmed that the delays in the others were almost always associated with inadequate information being provided in the application that was prepared by the states. We are looking at ways to try and improve that, particularly through the potential development of a new national monitoring system which might enable us to deal with applications in a semiautomatic fashion where information is readily available and would underpin the deliberations of the National Rural Advisory Council in assessing an area for declaration. So the ANAO report was constructive and helpful, but it was certainly also very supportive of the benefits of the drought assistance and the way in which it was delivered.

This particular legislation does make some significant improvements to the delivery of assistance to farmers. The Australian government remains committed to providing assistance directly to drought affected farmers and rural communities during these difficult times. Large areas of eastern Australia have been experiencing severe drought conditions since 2002 and, to further compound the situation, the first five months of 2005 in Australia have been the hottest and the second driest start to a year on record. As a result, farmers in 45 per cent of Australiaâs agricultural land are currently EC declared and eligible to apply for EC assistance.

As I mentioned earlier, the Prime Minister announced on 30 May another $254 million in a package of drought assistance measures, and that is a clear demonstration of this governmentâs proactive approach to assisting rural and regional Australians impacted by the drought. The existing measures, together with the enhancements announced by the Prime Minister, bring the Australian governmentâs expected commitment on drought assistance to over $1.25 billion. In total, under the EC arrangements and the additional drought assistance package announced on 9 December 2002, the government has approved more than 33,900 applications for income support and nearly 16,700 applications for interest rate relief for drought affected farmers. The enhancements in the package of measures announced on 30 May will mean more farmers will get increased assistance through more generous means tests for EC assistance, a continuation of the streamlined extension assessment process and a review by the National Rural Advisory Council of the 22 areas not extended in the past year.

Of course, rural communities impacted by this drought have not been forgotten. Drought affected communities will benefit from the package announced on 30 May 2005 and also through nearly $9 million in additional counselling and support services. I was happy to ceremonially hand over the $3 million cheque to the CWA with the Prime Minister today to assist with their emergency aid grants program. There will also be a $10 million Envirofund grants round to focus particularly on dealing with biodiversity in a drought and the sorts of issues which can perhaps be assisted during this period of time to make sure that the environment is also in a sound state to recover once the rains return.

The purpose of this bill is to implement the more generous means test for the exceptional circumstances relief payment that was announced on 30 May 2005. Because the government is providing a $10,000 exemption for off-farm income for ECRP, farmers who have been forced to obtain off-farm employment to supplement their farm income during this severe drought will not be disadvantaged over those who have not when it comes to accessing ECRP. The bill also streamlines the process for farmers obtaining EC certificates. The NFF has been advocating streamlined EC arrangements, and the need to have a more efficient and effective EC certificate process has been highlighted through the EC reform activities undertaken over the last two years. It was also one of the issues mentioned in the ANAO report.

In a whole-of-government approach, Centrelink taking over the responsibility for EC certificates from 1 October 2005 will mean that farmers will be automatically assessed for an EC certificate when they apply for the ECRP. The effect of this change will be a more consistent and accurate process for farmers obtaining EC certificates and, of course, it eliminates one of the pieces of paperwork that was associated with receiving EC assistance.

I thank honourable members for their support for the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005. The passage of this bill will ensure Australiaâs farmers are supported through this severe drought. Importantly, it will ensure that farmers are positioned to make a strong recovery when the drought breaks and to return Australian agriculture to being a valuable contributor to the Australian economy. I thank honourable members of the government in particular who have lobbied for these kinds of reforms. Some of the members have already spoken, such as the honourable member for Riverina, but unfortunately time precluded a number of other members from the government side who wished to speak on this legislation, including the honourable member for Paterson, who has just taken the chair.

Recognising how important drought reform has been, it has been an issue that has seriously dulled the spirits of people right throughout rural and regional Australia. They have been encouraged by the announcement by the Prime Minister of more assistance, and this legislation will help ensure that more Australian farmers in drought areas will be eligible for help and, when they get the help, it will be more generous. I commend the bill to the House.
