talk.start.para: âOn Saturday, 4 June I met with members of the Gravity Community Park Youth CommitteeâJordan Purcell, Kayla Iby, Chanetane Gudgeon, Kimberley Bargache, Rebecca Dunleavy and Nissa Harveyâat the Gravity youth centre in Lake Haven in the electorate of Shortland. They are a very impressive group of young people who are committed to bringing the dream of the Gravity community youth park to a reality. Gravity youth park is located within Lake Haven. It is in an area of Wyong Shire that has a high level of youth unemployment, with the 2001 census showing that the unemployment rate for 15- to 24-year-olds was around 20 per cent. It is an area that has a low socioeconomic background and the median wage is around $600 to $799 per week. Gravity youth centre has had an attendance of some 15,690 young people since September 2003 and has an average monthly attendance of 1,045. Two hundred and sixty local people have signed up and become formal members and regularly attend the centre.

speech.para: Gravity Community Park is an exciting project and it came directly from the inspiration of the young people. Within Lake Haven and Gorokan young people came together and decided that they wanted to change the negative perception of the area. They decided that they could do this by working together and consulting with the community. It is not an area that has been without problems. The centre has had its problems in the past, not from the young people who use it but from some of the other young peopleâand some older too, I might addâaround the area.

These young people are inspirational and this project is something that would inspire any member in this House. They want to come together and transform vacant land into a family friendly picnic area with a barbecue area, plant trees and gardens, build new pathways, community sculptures, mosaics and public seating and set up an amphitheatre where they can have community performances. It is really including the community in the youth centre, making it a living area and creating an environment where everyone will feel welcome.

To date the project has passed through a number of phases. It has been through the consultation process. Wyong council has gone through the draft project briefing. Between March and June this year they have undertaken the construction of the youth mosaics. Between February and April they commenced a WorkWise landscaping course and between now and November they need to bring about the final stages of the project. I have to acknowledge that both the Wyong Shire Council and Elcom have donated money towards this the project. I thank them for their support.
I would like to share some of the thoughts of the young people I met with on that day. I have a letter from Jordan Purcell in which he pointed out that the project was:

quote.para: Â ... initiated by young locals using the youth centre with aims to improve local recreational facilities, allow young people the opportunity to contribute to the planning of their community and help reform current attitudes towards youth.

speech.para: He invited sponsorship from local businesses, corporations and government bodies. The group is holding fundraising events to help. Kayla said:

quote.para: The project is encouraging all young people to get involved in something that they will enjoy ...

speech.para: Chanetane said:

quote.para: ... itâs a great place to be, my friends and I just love going there, as we love the people there, the youth workers.

speech.para: Kimberley asked for my support and the support of the community. Rebecca said that they really needed support for their project. Nissa said that there are so many good things about this place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to compliment Professor Patrick Parkinson and his task force on their final report on child support which was handed down last week. The report is balanced and it is in the best interests of the child. More importantly, the recommendations will provide additional fairness and equity for both parents. However, the problem is that, all good intentions aside, the report is only a worthless document until such time as the government commits to introducing the changes.

speech.para: I am particularly pleased with the central recommendation that the child support formula be changed to more accurately reflect the costs of raising a child and that both parentsâ self-support amount will be made the same. Allowing the cost of providing a home for children even if that is only for one day a week was also a key breakthrough for non-residential parents. The task force consideration of matters relating to paternity was also a step forward and would provide men incorrectly caught up in the child support system with greater opportunity for recourse. Those who were forced to pay large sums for travel to exert their contract rights would have that take into account during the assessment process.

The task force recommendation regarding additional income earned through a second job or overtime during the first five years after separation would be well received and struck a good balance for parents trying to re-establish themselves following family breakdown. I remain concerned, however, about the Child Support Agencyâs powers with regard to capacity to earn, but the task force has at least made it clear that a personâs state of health and other caring responsibilities should be taken into account. I raise this particular point because a number of my constituents, because of the financial pressures put on them, have taken their own lives.

I wanted to raise this issue and stress to Pru Goward, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the inequities in the Child Support Agency and the way it operates. I sent her a letter covering six very detailed submissions and I have to say that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner has shown significant commonsense on the subject and has been very fair on the emotive issue of child support. She has discussed at length with Professor Patrick Parkinson the issues raised within the case examples in my submission to her. In her response to my submission Commissioner Goward had this to say:

quote.para: It may be that, given the limits of the terms of reference of Professor Parkinsonâs review further investigation will be needed into the processes of the agency and its use of discretionary powers.

speech.para: She has obviously picked up the very real concerns within the submissions that I gave her about the draconian and intrusive powers of the Child Support Agency that Professor Parkinson unfortunately could not address in his terms of reference when he put together his report.

Given the Child Support Agencyâs disgraceful record with regard to decision making and its treatment of child support clients, I believe it is vital that the Child Support Agencyâs punitive powers be held up to scrutiny. In fact, now that Professor Parkinsonâs task force has done its job, the government should not only implement these changes but clean up the whole system by way of an independent inquiry into the Child Support Agency and how it operates with the draconian powers that I have described. When you read, as I have, the thousands of cases that I have received and which I am compiling in a database, you can understand why there needs to be an independent inquiry into the Child Support Agency and the way it operates to ascertain whether what it is doing is within the law and appropriate in this day and age in terms of accessing, as an example, the joint banking accounts of payers who have gone into a second relationship and who have had their bank accounts raided. It needs to be looked at. My view on this issue has been very public. I believe that the government should undertake an independent inquiry as quickly as it can to ensure that these unrealistic powers that the Child Support Agency has are looked into and removed as quickly as possible.

talk.start.para: âWill the minister give that?
âThat will depend, of course, on the commitment of the minister. To date, my experience of both ministers with responsibility for the portfolio is that they are yes ministers. (Time expired)

âI rise tonight to pay respect to the life of Frederick Douglas Quinane. Fred passed away in his 84th year on 8 June 2005 and is survived by his wife, Mary, his four children, Anne, Jack, Cate and Terry, and his grandchildren, Luke, Mary, Kiera, Annie, Paul, Corey, Patrick, Rhiannon and Michael, and his extended family. Fredâs life was celebrated last Tuesday at a Mass in the Sacred Heart Church in Pearce in Canberra. His daughter Anne and son Jack both spoke beautifully about their father and it was clear to all present that Fred Quinane was blessed by a very loving family. Anne and Jack spoke of Fredâs conviction, his high standards and strong character, his deep Christian faith and his abiding commitment to community service and to the disadvantaged. His fatherâs war service at Gallipoli had a lasting effect on Fred and his family.

speech.para: Fred left school at the age of 14 and worked at Murdochâs Menswear until his 18th birthday when he was sacked because his employer did not want to pay him adult wages. The lessons learnt at that early age stayed with Fred throughout his life and gave him a strong sense of duty and an enduring concern for others. When World War II broke out in 1939 Fred was prevented from enlisting because the factory he was working in was declared a protected defence industry. He kept trying and eventually succeeded in 1943. In 1946 Fred met his future wife, Mary. They were married in 1947 and moved to Canberra in 1948. Over the next 59 years they raised a family and from all accounts were blessed by many years of happiness. As with the story of any family, there were also sad times with the death of their second child, Kathleen, at age six months, and their fifth child, Paul, at age 27.

Fred had been a member of the ALP since the age of 14 in the St George area of Sydney and transferred his membership to the Canberra branch upon his arrival in 1948. In 1951 he was selected to lead the Labor team in the ACT Advisory Council elections and when the office of council chairman became an elected position in 1955 Fred won it unopposed. That Advisory Council later evolved into the ACT Legislative Assembly.

In 1959 Fred stepped back from political life but remained a dedicated public servant and continued to serve the community through his involvement with local charities, the Public Service and community projects. In the late 1950s Fred coordinated volunteers to build the OâDonnell Youth Centre in Braddon with their own hands. He then moved this volunteer work force on to build St Brigidâs Church in Dickson. In the late 1960s he was one of the leaders in the push for a Catholic club in Canberra. In 1971 he turned the first sod on the future site of the Canberra Southern Cross Club with club patron Bishop Morgan and he became the clubâs foundation president. Fred served as a member of the Southern Cross Club board for several terms and served one term as the national president of the Licensed Clubs Association.

He served on organising committees for charitable organisations like St Vincent de Paul and the Snow Foundation. He is remembered as a great leader and organiser who could elevate the performance and standing of any team. Fred worked tirelessly in several roles within the Public Service, including as the Senior Trade Commissioner in San Francisco. The trade commissioner service gave Fred the affectionate and unofficial title of âFather of the Trade Commissioner Serviceâ. For his professional achievements, Fred was awarded a Centenary of Federation Australian Public Service medal in 2001.

After retiring in 1981 Fred became the first executive director of the Canberra Association for Regional Development, the forerunner to the Canberra Business Council. He later became a member of the National Capital Planning Authority. There is a plaque on the corner of Northbourne Avenue and Alinga Street in Canberra city recognising his contribution as Chairman of the Advisory Council.

Fred Quinane will long be remembered as a loving father, grandfather, husband, co-worker, committed public servant, politician, charity worker, community leader and friend. I place on the record my appreciation and that of our community in Canberra to Fred for his commitment to public service, his love for friends and family and, most of all, for providing such a wonderful example, to all who met him, of a life well lived. Our sympathies, condolences and very warmest of wishes go to Mary and Fredâs family.

talk.start.para: âOn Sunday, 19 June I was privileged to be present at the farewell Pontifical High Mass and Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament at All Saints Anglican Church, Wickham Terrace, Brisbane. The bishop presiding was Bishop David Chislett SSC, who had been the Rector of All Saints, Wickham Terrace for a period of 10 years. The Primate of the Traditional Anglican Communion, Archbishop John Hepworth, was also present.
âHear, hear! Good man.

âHe is a good man. Unfortunately, Archbishop Aspinall has withdrawn the licence of Bishop Chislett because of Bishop Chislettâs support of Catholic orthodoxy in the Anglican Church. I believe that this action by Archbishop Aspinall seriously brings into doubt his moral fitness to be the Anglican Archbishop of Brisbane. In the minutes available to me, I want to state extracts from the farewell sermon by Bishop Chislett at the pontifical high mass.

quote.para: Today is one of the saddest days of my life. My heart is broken.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

I am sad beyond belief because being Rector of All Saintsâ Wickham Terrace has never been a âjobâ for me so much as being part of a FAMILY; and unlike other times when Iâve moved on, I have been forced to leave you against my will.

We have had ten good years together. They have been years of hard work. But they have also been years of blessing and growth. Together we have proclaimed and lived the Good News of Jesus right in the heart of this beautiful City of Brisbane, and we have seen many peopleâindeed, some of YOU here present todayâdiscover Jesus for the first time.
In fact, as I look out over the congregationâ

speech.para: and it was a full congregationâ

quote.para: my heart is touched by the presence of so many who have allowed me to share deeply in your life and death circumstances.

If there is something I want you to remember about my time with you, it is that together we became part of what Pope John Paul II called the New Evangelization. In other words, together we have brought men and women to know the Lord Jesus Christ as their Saviour. We have become âEvangelical Catholics.â Our hearts truly âburn within usâ as we allow Jesus to speak to us through the Scriptures, and we continually recognise him in the âBreaking of the Breadâ (Luke 24). I am reminded of some words of Pope Benedict when he was still just dear old âCardinal Ratzingerâ in May 2004:

âMany people perceive Christianity as something institutional rather than as an encounter with Christ, which explains why they donât see it as a source of joy. If we stay with this impression, we do not live the essence of Christianity, which is an ever new encounter, an event thanks to which we can encounter the God who speaks to us, who approaches us, who befriends us. It is critical to come to this fundamental point of a personal encounter with God, who also today makes himself present, and who is contemporary. If one finds this essential centre, one also understands all the other things. But if this encounter is not realized, which touches the heart, all the rest remains like a weight, almost like something absurd. We need to understand Christianity in a personal way, from the point of view of an encounter with Christ.â
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

Following my consecration, and then my suspension, I received so many personal letters of encouragement from Anglican, Continuing Anglican, Roman Catholic, Russian, Greek and Antiochan Orthodox leaders, indicating that they understand full well just how difficult it now is for those Anglicans who really believe the Catholic Faith. For example, a well-known Roman Catholic Monsignor (not from Brisbane Archdiocese), the author of a number of significant books, began his letter thus:
âDear Bishop David,

âPardon my tardiness, but please accept my belated congratulations on the great step taken. It had to be done, otherwise the decay and deceit would just roll on and on, as the good people drift and wander.

â... I have followed some of the responses, positive, vague, silly and downright nasty, and that confused range of reactions should assure you that taking a stand for Faith and Order is always costly.â

speech.para: I return to what Bishop Chislett said:

quote.para: For most of its history, All Saintsâ has stood firm for the undiluted Catholic Faith. Its people have always been taught that they are Catholics first and Anglicans second (the order we claim is required of us by our historic Anglican formularies). In fact, that is a summary! As I said in my Annual Meeting Address back in February, we are first of all CHRISTIANS; then we are CATHOLICS; then we are EVANGELICALS; and then, I guess, if after all that thereâs still some time left over, we are ANGLICANS! Thatâs our priority order. In that respect we are different to those parishes that merely have a âhigh churchâ flavour and believe in a separate religion called âAnglicanism.â In fact, Anglicans like us have been left between THE Rock and a Hard Place by the relentless departure of liberal Anglicanism from the Faith once delivered to the Saints in all sorts of different areas, but objectively and sacramentally in the ordination of women which, as so many women and men around here will tell you, destroys not just the iconic value of the nuptial imagery at the heart of the Scriptures, the Gospel and the Faith, but also our confidence in the sacramental life of dioceses like this one that have embraced the changes.

speech.para: I salute Bishop Chislett and his service to the faith.

talk.start.para: âI wish to bring to the attention of the House tonight an excellent program initiated in and near my electorate of Prospect called the Vietnam Vision Project. The Vietnam Vision Project involves 36 medical practitioners and support staff travelling to Vietnam to operate on people suffering from cataracts. This is the third year that this initiative has taken place. From 29 May 2005, for two weeks, six ophthalmologists, eight general practitioners, seven optometrists, two dentists, two pharmacists and support staff travelled to four provinces in the Mekong Delta and central Vietnam. Over 1,000 people received a vital cataract operation from this group. By way of interest, I note that the dentists play a particularly interesting role in this delegation to Vietnam. They actually play the role of the anaesthetist. Because the group was not able to find any anaesthetists to do the work required for a cataract operation, the dentists did the work of the anaesthetist.

speech.para: A report from the health ministry of Vietnam revealed that in 2003, over 460,000 people were suffering from bilateral blindness and 890,000 people were blind in one eye. Cataracts are the major cause of blindness for people over 50. I congratulate Vietnam Vision for the wonderful initiative of dealing with this health problem. The project was initiated, and is led, by Dr Phuoc Vo, a medical practitioner who is extremely active in many community organisations in my electorate and surrounding electorates.

Fundraising has been arranged by the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation in Australia and New Zealand and the Vietnamese-Australian Buddhist Assistance Trust. Funding support has also been given by the Rotary clubs of Cabramatta and Liverpool West, and the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Ophthalmologists. I congratulate each of these organisations. Each cataract operation costs around $A100. This program is for poor rural dwellers who have not received any help for cataracts in the past. These people are in great need of assistance and I congratulate everyone involved.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak this evening on a matter of great concern in my electorate. The north-west coast of Tasmania is known as one of Australiaâs greatest farming regions. Our red soils, clean air and abundant rainfall are the envyof farmers across the countryâmany of whom, as we know, are unfortunately struggling with the effects of a prolonged drought. With our natural advantages, Tasmaniaâs north-west coast grows some of the highest quality produce that you will find anywhere in the world, but this industry, the backbone of my electorateâs economy, is at risk due to an attitude of some corporate giants which can only be described as un-Australian.

speech.para: Companies such as McDonaldâs, Coles and Woolworths like to promote their fresh vegetables but what they do not tell you is how they continually demand that farmers accept ever lower prices for that produce. And, at the same time, the supermarket duopoly seems to give no second thought to importing produce from overseas and slapping on a common label. Increasingly, we are finding that âHomebrandâ does not mean âhome-grownâ, and justifiably the issue of country of origin food labelling has come to the fore.

I am proud that this government has made its position clear on mandatory food labelling and that it will in no way countenance the watering down of existing laws. For north-west Tasmanian farmers, however, the recent decision by McDonaldâs to end an exclusive deal for the supply of only Australian potatoes has dealt a savage blow. McDonaldâs decision led directly to Simplot Australia cutting potato contracts in the north-west coast of Tasmania by some 15 per centâa massive cut for an industry already struggling with low prices.

On Wednesday, thousands of people are expected to attend a rally across the road from the local McDonaldâs store in Devonport, to protest against this un-Australian decision, and I plan to be by their side. I stand 100 per cent behind farmers in my electorateâand those farmers throughout our nationâwho are demanding that companies such as McDonaldâs, Woolworths and Coles stop turning their backs on regional and rural Australia in the name of profits.

I would like to congratulate one north-west Tasmanian McDonaldâs franchisee for committing to use only locally grown potatoes. But this only raises the question of why McDonaldâs refuses to take the same stance at a national level. If the company can allow one of its franchisees to say that he will only stock French fries made from locally grown potatoes, why will it not direct that all its restaurants do likewise?

We know McDonaldâs does not like to be seen as a greedy, profit-driven multinational, and so it was no surprise to discover that it responded to the criticism. You can tell McDonaldâs is more than a little embarrassed, however, when you read the question-and-answer media statement it issued earlier this month, in which it is obvious the company failed to answer its own questions. For instance, McDonaldâs poses the question:

quote.para: Is it true that McDonaldâs doesnât treat its suppliers fairly?

speech.para: But instead of a straight no or yes, the answer was a hollow comment about long-term relationships with suppliers. And, of course, McDonaldâs does not even bother asking itself the question about whether it treats farmers fairly, because no amount of spin can explain the growersâ miserly share of every serve of fries sold. I wonder what consumers would think if they knew that farmers receive a miserly $225 a tonne for potatoes and McDonaldâs sells that same tonne for $18,200 as French fries.

This is also an issue about social conscience. Where does the drive for company profit end? The drive to profit at the expense of all else has no bounds as far as these companies are concerned. It is time that they realised their social responsibilities to our society and played fair with our producers. All producers are asking for is a fair price and a fair go. I appreciate that companies such as McDonaldâs, Woolworths and Coles employ a great many Australians, but in their pursuit of even greater profits they are putting at risk the viability of Australiaâs primary industries. I will be at the rally on Wednesday because I believe a message must be sent to companies such as McDonaldâs to show social responsibility. Importing potatoes when we grow the worldâs best, and at a competitive price, is simply un-Australian.

subdebateinfo.title: 112th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly, Manila, and a bilateral visit to the Solomon Islands

talk.start.para: âI wish to continue my speech earlier today on the delegation report of the bilateral visit to the Solomon Islands. The highlight of the visit was a 40-kilometre trip in an open boat from New Georgia Island to Gizo. speech.para: On behalf of the members for Riverina, Mackellar and Fraser, I express our special thanks to our High Commissioner in the Solomon Islands, Mr Patrick Cole, and his staff, and the leaders and staff of RAMSI and the aid agencies. I thank the government and the people of the Solomon Islands for their hospitality. And I should not forget to thank the boat driver, who brought us all safely through the stormâthere was no preselection needed in any of those electorates!
